content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Like the first game, Bioshock Infinite is a very thematically ambitious game. One that begins to elevate storytelling in gaming. There will surely be a lot of discussion to follow with this one. There's a lot of care taken with the world in which it takes place in, as well as with some of the themes it handles. And Bioshock Infinite opts to hold very little back. Here you'll be tackling themes such as racism, religion, false prophets, gender roles, even moments that will test your own morals. It's got a lot to say. The story and the world also come to life in the same way that Rapture does. While Columbia is not as dazzling as the trip into the underwater world, it does have a pulse just the same. You'll find Voxphones scattered throughout. These, like the original Bioshocks audio diaries, add a lot more to the tale at hand. They add to the story, the world and the atmosphere. To ignore them is to miss out on a considerable portion of the game. For those very curious about the world they're playing in, they will most certainly want to pick these up.The world of Columbia is wider and more open than the claustrophobic and enclosed Rapture, gun fights involve more enemies than the original Bioshock. The problem with this is that it devalues the fights itself. In the original Bioshock, enemies were something to fear. Even the most basic ones could do damage to you if you're not prepared. In Infinite, most enemies are just faceless guards who you just simply have to shoot in order to progress to other parts of the story. Most fights just end up repetitive, and though the game allows you to use various methods such as vigors and skyhooks to defeat enemies, rarely do you ever need to. Most of the game you're grossly overpowered, even if you're not upgrading your vigors or weapons.Another thing, though admittedly it's a nitpick, the dissonance between the beautiful story and the violent shooting is something worth mentioning. Sometimes the dialogue and the "breather" scenes seem to be slightly disrupted by the high amounts of adrenaline shooting that follows. It's not enough to ruin the experience, but it's certainly something that could be done better. Less emphasis on gunplay and maybe some more exploration elements could benefit this game.Bioshock Infinite isn't a perfect game, but it is a great one. A thematically ambitious game with a well told story, Bioshock Infinite is sure to delight fans who fell in love with the original back in 2007. It is a game that not only delivers well from a gameplay standpoint, but from a narrative one as well. If you enjoyed exploring the world of Rapture in 2007, then you'll love going through the land of Columbia, here.

Note: Play the games in this orderBioshock 1 > Bioshock 2 > Bioshock InfiniteThe year is 1912 and you play as Booker DeWitt and you've been tasked with saving  a girl, Elizabeth , in the city of Columbia. The game is an Action FPS that is true to its genre. The game offers a fairly fast paced action that might sometimes feel a bit tedious. Bioshock Infinite contains a multitude of weapons that are era specific and are lovely to use.You also have access to powers, known as vigors, which you can use to dispose of enemies or to just help you make your way through the game. The vigors can also be combined with each other making it an intriguing system to play around with.In addition to Weapons and Vigors you have other tools, like the skyhook, which lets you jump around from hooks attached to the side off certain buildings.The stealth system within the game is good. The detection is based around both sound and vision so walking on a carpet can suppress your footsteps while walking on puddles of water or broken glass will make them louder.The games scenery and enviroments are absolutely outstanding. When I got the first glimpse of Columbia I was speechless. The voice acting in the game is great as well with excellent dialogue. I'm quite serious now, I can't describe how PERFECT some parts were with how the characters acted and what they said. This game has brought forward some amazing quotes. In addition to that, all of the characters are well made and very sympathetic. I like games that have a good story, and Bioshock Infinite has just that. The story  is incredibly rich when it comes to content and will leave you with memorable parts that will make you smile when you think back.Bioshock Infinite is a game that you will not regret playing. It's fantastic.edit - removed Chrono order to please people.

												I don't think I've ever fancied a video game character before Elizabeth... Whilst my hours on steam don't reflect my actual playing time, as I've completed this game way too many times on my PS3, I just can't express how much I love this. It's my favourite ever game, and here's why:1) The plot is incredible, and has real substance. I've never completed a game more than once before, because I find playing the same story line tiring. However, this is an exception. The story line is phenomenal. I find myself being totally, and utterly, immersed in the world of Columbia. I have a real sense of "belonging" within the game which sounds a bit weird, but I don't really know how I can explain it. Brooker DeWitt and Elizabeth are both very strong characters, with great backstories, and the way these stories collide with each other is thought provoking, fantastically executed and cleverly directed.2) The graphics are visually stunning. The joy of playing this game with ultra settings, is one to be behold. If you're looking for a game with a wealth of detail, this is the one. Characters and scenery look great in the cut scenes and during game play. The lighting is just right throughout, and to me, fire has never before looked so good.3) The characters are strong, witty, and badass. And whoever voiced the characters need a medal, because I couldn't imagine anyone else stepping up to deliver what these guys have delivered. 4)  Combat. Is. Awesome. I never really liked gore in a game before, but I really enjoyed this, with just the right amount of gore included. Not just that, it's really easy to pick up which I love, and seem to have trouble with in other games.The only real criticism I can think of is the lack of DLC's available, and wishing that the story went on just that little bit longer. I didn't want it to end. Other than that, I really can't fault it. You're not just buying a game here, you're literally buying an entire world. Three hundred thumbs up from me!

												What drives a man of God to wash away the sins of his past, only to blacken his heart with a multitude more? How far can a freedom fighter be pushed before virtue and righteousness are replaced by a lust for vengeance? What does a privileged society do when the foundation of its prosperity is shaken? BioShock Infinite dares to explore these heady themes and many more, giving you glimpses at just how the seemingly smallest of decisions can forever alter our realities, and our hearts. As an agent provocateur in the fantastical floating city of Columbia, your actions bring turmoil and strife to an ostensibly idyllic landscape. It's immensely fun to stir up trouble, and even more engaging to see how boldly BioShock Infinite portrays a society torn asunder. You'll be haunted by this thematically devastating adventure, and indeed, its phenomenal final minutes, which are bound to be discussed and dissected for some time to come. Superb!

Posted: May 1, 2014
												Rise above the clouds and say hello to the city of Columbia, a place that changes the whole concept of how a video game should look.It's hard to say when Infinite evolved from a regular sequel into a terrific piece of art, but here it is. Even though it seems to ignore pretty much everything the original BioShock had to offer in terms of narration, the game not only bears the same idea but also expands it widely, moving the series far beyond any borders.The story now is much, much more complex. A standard rescue quest soon turns into a great adventure full of amazing twists, also featuring tons of different references, including physics, philosophy, religion, politics and many other things. By the way, it doesn't apply to the base game only — the Burial at Sea DLCs are necessary for understanding the wonderful cycle of the series. No examples here, for the whole story is worth seeing.Not to mention the gameplay mechanics which appear to be a simplified variation of the first game's scheme: easy enough to keep the fast pace and yet deep enough to let the player choose their way of dealing with problems. No more hacking mini-games or complicated stealth tactics, though, but if one is looking for some challenge, there is always 1999 mode that can make it feel like home. These facts, together with detailed design and, of course, outstanding visuals, make it hard to deny that the BioShock franchise is nearing perfection. Irrational Games use every single instrument the gaming industry has discovered to make their own beautiful symphony — and to finally make a perfect distinction between mediocre video games and a masterpiece.

												Whoever says games can't be considered "Art" probably never played any BioShock game.BioShock Infinite brings entertainment to another level, I haven't had fun with a game for a long time. That doesn't mean all the others releases are bad but it's been a while since i had so much fun playing a game.The plot it's one of the best i've seen in my entire gaming life, matching some Visual Novels and books i love (i kinda like a good plot and not the usual mindless action or generic shooting gallery we get most of the time). I don't think you'll find another game with a better quality plot anytime soon.Graphics aren't realistic but that doesn't mean they are bad, they got kinda a unique style that makes everything beautiful. You could say they are the same as the older games but they certainly improved a lot. However i kinda get annoyed with the excessive "bloom" in some scenes, sometimes they are overused to the point of blinding you. Aside from that everything else is beautiful. There's the music, honestly it isn't great but it's not bad either, the combat music is the same for the whole game save some specific scenes and it gets repetitive after a while. It's average at best.The gameplay is what you've already seen in BioShock 1 & 2 with some improvements. You can equip gears that gives you a few improvements like auto-casting lightning when you are struck or put your enemies on fire when you strike them with melee attacks.There's the new "Sky-Line" mechanic that allows you to travel around the place and can even be used in your advantage during combat, your partner Elizabeth even rides with you.And talking about Elizabeth, that's one hell of a companion. She is like Alyx in Half-Life 2: Episode One but instead of fighting she gives you support during and outside combat like finding and giving you ammo, salt, money and even warning about points of interest and some missable items like lockpicks. I love when i'm almost out of ammo and she throws me some ammo, she also plays a huge role in the plot.Honestly i haven't cared about my companion in a single-player game since Alyx, she isn't useless like most companions who doesn't do jack aside from yelling at you all the time like 'AIM DOWN YOUR SIGHTS", " TAKE POINT", "THEY ARE KILLING US DO SOMETHING!!!". PC port is above average, there isn't much graphics options but at least the game runs great, without vsync the game always run above 60fps (sometimes going up to 90fps) with everything maxed out and the game has some pretty graphics.It took me around 13 hours to beat the game.My rate: 9,5

												Having played the main story on the hardest setting and completed all the DLCs I have to say: I absolutely love BioShock Infinite. Positive:- Extremely beautiful and atmospheric settings - as to be expected of a BioShock game- Fantastic, intense and unexpected storyline- DLCs actually deliver new and exciting storylines and game play- Great voice-acting and music overall- Responsive controls- I enjoyed only being able to hold two weapons at a time (unlike the other two BioShock games). It allows you to adjust to the situation by providing different weapons for you to pick up, or stick to your preferred play-style without scrolling through a huge inventory of weapons- No escorting: Elizabeth takes care of herself and helps you from time to time- You are rewarded for exploring- Challenging battles that remain exciting throughout the gameNegative:- I always found it strange that you take fall damage, but not when jumping off the sky line- Personally I found the crows + shock jockey combo to be extremely over-powered - The main story is only approximately 10 hours long- Less exploration than BioShock 1 and 2- Quite linear Conclusion:If you like BioShock then Infinite is a must - it delivers what you would expect plus more. Fantastic game-play, intensely atmospheric environments, unforgetable story, and DLCs that connect Infinite to the original BioShock games (it will blow your mind). This is the only game I have ever pre-ordered and I do not regret it at all.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Where do I even begin? I had a great time playing Bioshock Infinite. I managed to complete it twice, and am considering a third playthrough. Similar to previous games, the story is original and very well written. It kept me interested throughout the game and despite my initial apprehension towards Elizabeth’s naïve character; I ended up really liking her as a “sidekick”, because that’s essentially what she is throughout the entire game. I enjoyed the numerous twists and turns of the story, and the ending absolutely blew me away.The gameplay is one of my favourite elements of Infinite. The new Skyrail system has transformed the dark and linear corridors of Rapture into a vast and open battlefield. The weapons are great fun to use, including the audio, with piano key drops that blare out when you land a headshot (soooo satisfying). The plasmid equivalent vigor abilities are nothing too special. Some are similar to previous Bioshock games while others introduce new things like forming a protective shield to absorb bullets and blast them back at your foes. There are some interesting combinations you can do with the vigor’s, which leads to many choices during combat.When compared to its predecessors, I felt Infinite lacked the horror elements that made me such a big fan of the first two games. In Rapture, everything was dark and gloomy so horror came naturally. In the floating city of Columbia, it was much harder to feel like it was part of the Bioshock universe. The secondary antagonist, Songbird is creepy and he does his best to keep the Big Daddy theme going, but the lack of creepy enemies just upset me. The boys of sound and sirens were my most anticipated enemies that I saw in the trailers for the game, but they had such a small role in the final game. Despite the lack of horror, Infinite managed to make me question my own understanding of what Bioshock is about and gave me lasting memories of a truly epic game.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Although it's a simplistic, heavily scripted, linear experience, it's one of the most optimized, visually appealing, interesting ones available. It's been a while since a game compelled me to write a review and if the price is right, I can absolutely recommend Bioshock Infinite.Unique aspects of Bioshock worth notingElizabeth's Pathfinding, Awareness & Helpfulness. In years prior many companions in games would get you caught, waste all of your ammo, die, or block you from progressing all while being totally silent. Elizabeth will toss you ammunition or money should she find any, will move out of your way if you walk close to her and will constantly make remarks about her surroundings.The use of the Sky Hook and Skylines. Sure, conventional methods of transportation are just fine and dandy but it certainly never hurts to think outside the box! It's quite an enjoyable experience zipping throughout Columbia on the Skylines while fighting enemies.Aspects of Bioshock Infinite worth praising● No Third Party Digital Rights Management. No limited amount of machine activations, no "always online" requirements, and no services other than Steam you need to sign into to play.● The Achievement Progress Saving System. You can reload checkpoints to accumulate kills and loot containers. And if you were to ever miss any Voxophones, Telescopes or Kinetoscopes,  you can simply go to "Load Chapter" and select the chapter you believe you missed it on and collect it. However, you have to be weary about Infusions as they have to be obtained in a consecutive playthrough.Aspects of Bioshock Infinite worth criticizing● No In-Game Option To Toggle HUD or Holster Weapon! This is an unfortunate trend in many 2K Games and 2K Games affiliate products going back years. Honestly, what's the point in developing such beautiful scenery if you're not going to have the ability to take screenshots of it without a Health bar, Shield bar, Vigor bar, your arm and your gun getting in the way?● 2 Weapon Limitation. In previous Bioshock titles you had access to a wide range of different weapons via a weapon wheel. This time around it's limited to just two weapons.● Lackluster amount of choices or alternative endings. For a game that's circled around infinite parallel universes with infinite possibilities, why does Bioshock Infinite have such a lackluster amount of meaningful choices or any sort of alternate ending? It's debatable if Bioshock Infinite really needed any but I certainly wouldn't want to be the individual aruguing for less.Development disagreements & degradation of the product!Bioshock Infinite was originally going to be more of an open world game with a variety of features but with disagreements in development accompanied with the limitations the product was facing on other platforms, they decided to scrap most of what they were working on to create the version you see before you. The product Irrational Games showcased at E3 2010 is significantly different compared to the product that's available to the consumer.Not every game has to have more than one ending, stealth mechanics, weapon customization, a third person player view, character customization, a variety of meaningful choices, manual save mechanics, modification development tools or have no scripted moments to be a decent game. Sure, any one of these features would have been great additions and dispite of the downgrade, I can absolutely recommend Bioshock Infinite if the price is right.

												OH MY GOD.The game sure did not get 94/100 from Metacritic for no proper reason.It's full of things to do, Main quest, Lots of side missions, Things to collect like weapon upgrades, Skill upgrades and Passive abilities, and of course, Easter Eggs to look for.The scenery you see in game is just amazing. Totally mind-blowing if you ask from me. It ranges from Rainy Seashore to up the skies in the Floating City, and all the way down to deep bottom of the Ocean. And the best part, you don't need very powerful computer for this game to funtion properly. I played with the 2nd lowest graphics, had my fps constant, and still was stunned by the beautiful views. Apart from landscape, the gameplay part is absolutely well-made.The gameplay contains mainly shooting and puzzles.The weapon models look really nice, and there are no bugs at all with animations.Some of the guns barrels even turn shining red from heat caused by constant shooting.You can blow your enemies up with RPG, shoot them as full of holes as Swiss Cheese,Abilities that you can use to turn your enemies into piles of ash, or to skyrocket them million miles away.Of course you don't need to always kill everyone. The game let's you choose most of the time whether to shoot or to stay in stealthy mode, looking out for threats and staying in shadows.The characters are easy to identify with.You just want to sit and keep playing, because the story is so entertaining and addictive.You want to see what's next, what is behind the next corner, what kind of enemies will you face.And, to be honest, there are merely no games without any bugs nowadays.I am talking about visual bugs, possible glitches and getting out of bounds.The bugs i got never killed me or prevented me to continue my adventure.For example, sometimes NPCs walked on places where they shouldn't have walked, Like on walls.But if you're into that kind of stuff, like i am, you're gonna find yourself going to places you were not supposed to go, and trying to find your way inside buildings, or outside areas, where you never was meant to be at.When i realized the credits were about to roll, i was a bit disappointed about the length of the game.It took me 14 hours to complete all the side missions, and main quest.It's not a long game, but it's very enjoyable. There's a lot of replay value too. Personally, that was one of the best Singleplayer shooters i've ever played. Totally recommended.Thanks for reading, hopefully this helped.-Nate

												I've always found the Bioshock universe interesting and really well done, unfortunately i dont really enjoy horror atmospheric games like Bioshock 1 & 2. This is exactly the reason i choose Bioshock Infinite. Bioshock infinite manages to put down a really good atmosphere just like part 1 and 2, it's kinda like this 1800's overly happy/goodlife style. And except for 1 or 2 horror atmospheric parts i really enjoyed walking through the flying and colorful world of Columbia. The scenery in this game is so amazing and i found myself often just standing still and enjoying the view.On to something different: The story and it's characters. Both are really interesting and well done. The story keeps itself interesting by introducing new things all game long. And by looting the world you'll find basic things like salt's, ammo, health etc. but also voxophones, these are audiofragments which expand on the story and give you more background information.  Someting i liked alot about Bioshock Infinite was the fact you travel with Elizabeth almost the whole game. It's something different, and although she doesnt really do much other than provide you with supplies and a bit of talking, it's better than traveling alone. However something you might need to do is search online for a explanation of the ending, because it's a really complex ending. There's alot of video's and sites explaining it, so it shouldn't be a problem finding something about it.Overall Bioshock Infinite is a amazing game, great story, great characters, great mechanics and a wonderfull world to explore. It's definitely a game that will keep you to thinking for a long time after you finished it.

												Taken as pure First-Person Shooters, Bioshock Infinite is not too different from past incarnations of the brand, resulting therefore in level (if not below) of many other productions of the same kind. The point is that define Bioshock Infinite a shooter would be an understatement, almost wrong. That created by Irrational Games is an experience almost essential for a video game that you define. A video game where sensory, emotional involvement and narrative, really make the difference going to erase the "flaws" from a revamped gameplay. Columbia is completely different from Rapture-is a cross-section of the contradictions of the American Society of the early ' 900: a world in which dive as in reading a good book, rich in facets and details, warm and welcoming; complete. It is an experience of great impact, capable of developing in us a strong empathy towards the protagonists, and let us rejoice and suffer with them at all times. It is one of the highest forms of art in gaming, where knowledge and freedom of expression are combined to form a mosaic that cannot leave indifferent. Bioshock Infinite is a far from perfect game, with many flaws, but you can't not love; It is impossible not to want. Why Bioshock Infinite is one of those productions that leave a mark in the game industry and the player, coming long remember and increasing the personal baggage.

Posted: October 9, 2014
												This game was actually a very pleasant surprise, particularly since i got it on sale just to try it out, and im glad to say it was well worth it.The game is a decent FPS with great graphics and smooth gameplay, characters are very well written, there is a reason to care what happens to them, the game provides a satisfying challenge on ultimate difficulty, there are no severe or gamebreaking bugs, havent experienced a single crash after 70+ hours of gameplay, the challenges and achievements all unlock properly and accordingly. However there are 2 aspects of the game which imo make it an above average shooter- the story and the game companion.The story is a deep, memorable, open for interpretation type, borderline philosophical, which sticks with you for some time even after you close the game. It did however take me 2 playthroughs to completely understand it, but i value the effort put into the story and how throughout the game they slowly reveal details to you, just to give you a totally unexpected finale.As for the follower/game companion, this game offers the most likable and usefull companion ive ever seen in a singleplayer game. I personally dont like followers because in most games they just block me in corridors, alert enemies to my presence, set off traps or make stupid remarks. Luckily Liz doesnt do any of these things and she also throws you ammo/health during combat when youre low, which makes you want to keep her around. The game comes with 2 DLCs- Clash in the Clouds (combat challenge based) and Burial at Sea. While ive enjoyed the main game and CitC DLC very much for above stated reasons, the events that take place in Burial at Sea DLC were at least from my point of view very confusing and anticlimatic. Probably because i havent played BioShock 1 or 2 prior to this game, and their stories are bound.CONCLUSIONNot to bother with numeric evaluation, lets just say i find this game to be exceptional. If you can, try this game out, absolutely recommended!

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												BioShock Infinite is the final entry in the BioShock franchise, and while it's quite different from the previous two games, I think it's a good way to end; especially once you play through Burial at Sea - Episode Two; but I'll talk about that in its own review. This one will talk exclusively about the main game, while I'll write reviews for each of the DLCs. So, on to the review!What should I talk about first? I guess gameplay would be an important factor. In BioShock Infinite, the combat feels more frenetic; so to speak. Rather than focusing on exploration like the previous games, you'll usually move from one combat arena to the other; not literally, of course, there will be moments where you're free to explore a bit, but the game still feels pretty combat oriented. Not that it's something bad, considering that, in my opinion, the combat in this game is pretty good, with lots of options to dispatch enemies; from the different weapons, to the Vigors (Infinite's version of Plasmids), and Elizabeth's Tears. If there's something I'd complain about, though, is the fact that you're limited to carrying two weapons at the same time. Somewhat disappointing, but the variety of Vigors (and Vigor Combos) more than makes up for this. Also, the Sky-Hook is a great addition, allowing you to quickly move through certain areas, while also working as a melee weapon. Finally, there's the Tears. Elizabeth, who will be your companion for most of the game, can open them to bring things to help you out during combat, which is quite useful.As for the story, well, it's pretty good in my opinion. It starts out somewhat "normal"; you're a guy sent to the city of Columbia to rescue a certain girl, but as it progresses, it gets more and more complex, in a good way. The characters are all pretty well written in my opinion, and a particular mention goes to the Lutece twins. Their dialogue always cracks me up a bit. Some people might feel that the main character, Booker, feels like a "regular" hero; you know, guy with a dark past, atoning for his sins, etc. Well, I'd say that's because, while being the playable character, Booker isn't the main character. The main character would be Elizabeth, and when you play through the game, it kinda makes sense. The story isn't about Booker's trip to Columbia, but rather about Elizabeth escaping from Columbia.And now, I'll dedicate a paragraph to Elizabeth. Like I mentioned above, I feel that the game is more about Elizabeth than about Booker. After all, she is kind of the driving force behind the plot; what moves it forward. And like I also mentioned, she'll be your companion for most of the game. Even then, the game doesn't feel like a long escort mission. During combat, Elizabeth helps you out; not fighting enemies directly, but by providing you supplies, opening tears to bring in help, and even warning you of powerful enemies. Outside combat, she'll wander on her own; not going too far away from you, but she'll still look at things that interest her, and might even find things you missed; she can also open doors for you through lockpicking. I think they did a great job at giving her a personality; she doesn't feel like another NPC at all, but rather as an actual person. Still, there are a few details here and there; just as an example, when lockpicking, she'll usually talk in a cheerful tone, which can feel out of place when, only a few minutes before, she was angry at Booker for something he did.The environments are superb. The city of Columbia is a pretty beautiful place, and I can see why they went with the "city in the sky" theme rather than going back to the bottom of the ocean. Not to say that Rapture wouldn't have looked good; in fact, you'll get to visit it in its prime in Burial at Sea! However, having a different setting was interesting, with 1912's Columbia providing a nice contrast to 1950's Rapture. The level design, by itself, is pretty good; still, most of the places you'll visit feel like combat arenas, consisting of big, open spaces, unlike Rapture's labyrinth-like structure. The soundtrack is pretty good as well.Well, I think that's all I can say about BioShock Infinite. Personally, my favourite BioShock game is BioShock 2, but even then, I think Infinite is an excellent game, which is why I recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Considering no one has made a fully objective review that analyzes actually positive aspects of this game, I took it upon myself to make one.Let's start with the bad aspects. Mainly, the gameplay. Bioshock had revolutionary gameplay; plasmids were extremely versatile and can be used for many things. Solving puzzles, starting attack combos, destroying machinery, and more. Along with the customization of upgrades and gear and great stealth mechanics, Bioshock had stellar gameplay and was different than almost all FPS's of it's time. That is, until Infinite showed up.The game is mechanically fun. The soundtrack and noises are amazing, and help set up the atmosphere and establish that Booker is ruthless and indifferent. The gameplay is also pretty rad in that setting up traps and using a combination of vigors is always fun. Objectively, however, it does not compare with the first game. Almost no puzzles can be solved with the vigors, and everything is pretty linear. It's strange that Infinite tries to go for an almost open world gameplay style where you can go back to places you've already visited for extra bonuses, considering it's pretty damn linear. It doesn't blend well, and going back a mile is not really good design. I don't think the average person would go back at all.The gameplay is also somewhat repetitive. At times it seems like the average AAA title where you're just filling random people coming at you with lead. The system where you can see where you're supposed to go to finish a quest/mission is pretty awful too. Sure, Infinite might have needed it considering theres so much to visit and you may be confused with the addition of skylines, but it's still not very good design. It's blatantly telling you, "hey, go here to finish the quest!"Some design choices were also awful. Probably the only formidable foe is the handyman (which is btw, practically a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ big daddy rip off), and it only shows up like 3 times. Another design choice that annoyed me was the failed potential of Elizabeth's prowess. You would think opening up rifts to different universes would be awesome, but no. Instead, it's literally just summoning ammo and guns from nowhere.I'll cut the wall of text- the gameplay is more mediocre than the first Bioshock. It's not revolutionary and it has its fair share of flaws. It's still pretty damn cool though, and I'd personally say the gameplay is better than most Triple A gameplay.To say I didnt enjoy it is completely wrong. As a narrative, the game is amazing.Sure, most people don't play games as a medium of critical storytelling- literature and film exist, after all. However, games can easily show critical value and Infinite represents this.The characters grow increasingly complex as you see more of their dialogue. Booker is extremely interesting. He's completely desensitized to everything- yet so fragile. It is commonly shown that Booker hardly hesitates when it comes to death and dismay. When asked about this, he even states, "One thing I've learned, if you don't draw first, you don't get to draw at all." It is suggested that the events he's been through at the battle of wounded knee made him the person he is. The event adds significant internal strife to his character; he knows he's done wrong and sinned, and he can't do anything to fix it. As stated by him, "You think a dip in the river is gonna wash away the things I've done?" Perhaps the highlight of his corrupt mind is shown when (major spoilers) he even gives away his daughter in attempts to repay his gambling debts. His fragility is shown throughout the game as well, especially torwards the end. Unlike his character, he starts to deeply care for Elizabeth and puts himself in extremely wreckless situations in attempts to protect her. When she tries to kill Comstock, he tells her that instead they should just relax in paris. He wants to run away rather than confronting Comstock. He refuses to be  baptized at the last second, showing his common trait of wanting to run away. He is emotionally scarred and he continues to prefer running away than confrontation at many times. He becomes extremely protective of Elizabeth to the point where it's obsessive and wants to prevent her from harm. It isn't much of an exaggeration to say he's fragile.Elizabeth is also a deeply interesting character. Being caged throughout her whole life and forced to have only the companion of a mechanical bird, Elizabeth desires freedom and relishes it. She's stuck between a rock and a hard place- she can go back to her tower and be restrained and watched her whole life, or go with Booker to whatever the ♥♥♥♥ and be utilized to get rid of his gambling debts. She does care for Booker, though she doesn't show it often. Also with the strange ability of opening rifts to different timelines, it is suggested she feels somewhat alienated from humanity. Given that she practically has a massive hatred torwards everyone and every group throughout the game including booker and yet she's forced to stay strong and go with Booker, her character is pretty tragic.Finally, the Vox Populi is really damn cool. It's much more than just a terrorist group with guns; they were so obsessed with gaining liberty and freedom that it turned into something much different. They changed from fighting for justice to fighting simply just for actual blind hatred torwards Comstock and his people. This is easily exemplified with Fitzroy about to kill the child just because of plain hatred for his family and their increasingly brutal standards for killing enemies. The concept of Columbia was bound to have internal strife, and the Vox Populi illustrates this well.Not only are the characters are well made, but also the intricate plot.It's a highly intelligent story, yet it doesn't try to flaunt it and end up being pretentious. The ending, like the first game, is a complete plot twist. It changes everything you know about the characters. Who the Lutece Twins really are, who Comstock really is, what elizabeth represents, and more. The game is truely a masterpiece in delivery, and at too many times during the ending I had my mouth open when I realized in my head what happened. You can also find out more about the plot the more you listen to the voxophones you find during the game. It is safe to say that Infinite's plot by far interested me more than any film or book I've ever read. Not to mention, the backgrounds/graphics and the soundtrack are all godly. They all are good at establishing the atmosphere of the game, and even standalone they're amazing. The game is a masterpiece. Sure, maybe the gameplay may not be truely exceptional, but when every other category excels, the setting is extremely creative, and the gameplay isn't as flawed as the average AAA title, it is safe to say the game is a masterpiece. Also, on a subjective note, I still found the game fun as hell despite the design flaws and I'm sure you will too.

Posted: November 9, 2015
												(Completed on consoles)Even with my very high expectations there are things in the game that really shocked me. This game combines identity, guilt, belief, narrative, revolution, race, national identity into one of the most brilliant and remarkable creative feats I have experienced. Taking place in an alternate 1912, you play as a handsome Booker DeWitt wrecked with debt that can only be revived by rescuing a girl from Columbia. The world revolves around a floating city fashioned by Comstock who turn an ulternate America into a religion. Columbia ferrocious thrive for racial purity stems a discontent for violent change. With this brilliant metaphysical story takes the player in a journey best discovered at a slow pace. What is so extraordinary about Bioshock Infinite is how it highlights the human needs and the choices that we make as a person. Everything from its art direction to its narrative is numbing in its inventiveness. Bioshock Infinite is filled with extraordinary details in every moment manifesting from audio logs to level designs. To rush through Bioshock Infinite is to miss one of the greatest pleasures in video games. One of the most impressive accomplishments is its casts of character and especially Elizabeth's appearance throughout the game. The relationship that slowly involves and metamorphosize between you that is the central thrust in the story. The success is its sublime design and animations that turns Elizabth into the most striking character I've seen in any creative media. Elizabeth earned my affection and throughout the journey as I actually cared for her. Gameplay incorporates smooth and precise action sequences. Boss fights in mid sections change up the players vitality and it's all driven by an amazing sound score that raise these moments to extreme heights. The arial combat of the grabbling hook is fresh and a wonderous achievement as it keeps you in constant rush of adrenaline. It was impossible for me to say goodbye in the end. Bioshock Infinite will be the game of the century and will remembered for as long as I live. Just buy it and get lost in its masterfulness.☆☆☆☆☆ /5 stars

I know I'm 4 years late with a review of this game but I feel an urge to express my opinion about my favourite game, so here it is... The plot : Bioshock Infinite takes place on a floating utopia named Columbia (year 1912) where you play the role of Booker DeWit, a private investigator that recieved the job of finding a girl named Elizabeth and that way to erease his "debt".The beautiful city of  Columbia  is at the surface a perfect place with perfect people but exploring and advancing in it you will find its dark moldy face. The city is the representation of extreme nationalism and religious fanaticism at its finnest form: propaganda posters and papers,patriotic music,rigorous clothing and behavior and the glorification showed to Zachary Comstock aka "The Prophet".I'm not going to enter in the  story  trying to avoid any possible spoilers, but I must say it's the most outstanding storyline I have ever encountered in my life.  <You are going to cry after a scrappy rusted fu***ng bird.>  Advancing in the city and learning its hidden controversated history it's a delight. Finding out about Booker life and Elizabeth secrets and true self it's going to keep you bonded with them the whole game.It is the most mindf**k story I have seen in a game/movie/tv show/book untill now. You are gonna start questionig every little detail of the world and the story in the hope of understanding the game and find yourself in need to take some notes to not be overwhelmed by it. The story it's hard to comprehend, raising many questions and theories, but that is its beauty.Regarding the  graphics ,  level design ,  game/gunplay  its perfect: graphically it is beautiful having an amazing verge between the "bright side" of the supposedly perfect place and the dark side of the story/true city. The gameplay it's easy to learn, the gunplay its smooth and basic (being there a gun for every category: pistol, handcannon, sniper, automatic, semi-automatic weapon having the option to upgrade them at the vending machines). The new part comes with  the vigors  which make the gameplay more fun (having the options to possess,freeze,stun <etc> your enemies). And also you can find gear that enhance certain abilities.  The melee weapon  can be used to travel across the zipline network of the city, that way being able to observe the beautiful level design and kill some patriots, of course. Ultimately , this is not just a game for me, it's a masterpiece. Ken Levine and his team from Irrational Games did the best job with Infinite: the combination between breathtaking story, well established characters, outstanding graphic work and fluid gameplay is all I can demand from a game developing studio.10/10 I would play again and start questioning about the size and the possibilities of the universe, realising that my mortal life is nothing in the long run for this obscure,dark place we exist in. Ps. If you want more story,the answers for some questions and the link between Infinite and the first two games Burial at Sea Episode 1 and 2 is there for you.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Bioshock Infinite is essentially an overhyped hallway shooter. At first the atmosphere and city seem full of potential, but as you proceed through the game, all of it disappears and is replaced by mixed feelings of boredom and dread. This isn't because the enemies or environment are frightening or intimidating, but because playing the game quickly goes from 'a promising Bioshock sequel' to 'tedious mob-killing chore oh god let me finish this game already'. Progress in Infinite is akin to cutting through thick vegetation in the jungle while waist deep in giant python-infested waters, only without the danger, suspense, and adventure that would come with such an expedition.One would imagine that such a setting as a floating city would be an incredible feature on it's own, but alas, even the very world you play in falls flat on it's face and doesn't bother getting up, opting to roll awkwardly to it's destination instead. It is entirely forgettable that you're in a floating city once you begin to proceed through the game. Perhaps it's because rather than being able to explore the city and be reminded that you're miles in the sky, you end up just walking through one straightforward area filled with bullet sponges to the next. Where the Bioshock games allowed the player freedom of movement around whatever section of Rapture they were in, Bioshock Infinite instead holds the player's hand and leads them down one corridor to the next; the game's map design is basically a big, fat, straight line. Previously it would take some degree of exploration and attention to move onwards. Infinite, meanwhile, decides that it's done with all that non-linearity business, and makes sure there's an abundance of giant doors with comically oversized flashing locks on them so you know exactly which end of the hall goes to the next area. After you kill all the enemies there, get ready to fight more of them. Waves after waves of them, until the end of the game. Perhaps the worst part of all is that all of the main features that people were pumped for were instead revealed to be nothing like expected:Those cool sky-rails that seemed to have so much potential? Almost exclusively used to circle around whatever area you happen to be mowing down baddies in.Elizabeth having fun and dynamic interdimensional powers capable of smashing bad guys with items or having offensive and/or interesting combat use? They instead spawn in robots, skyhooks, cover, and guns/health/salts in a few predetermined places.Those giant handymen that seemed like they'd be fun replacements for Big Daddies? Get ready to fight two of them in the entire game.The giant bird that was anticipated so much and seemed like you'd have an amazing showdown with? You never fight it.Expecting a pit-in-your-stomach feeling as you plummet towards the earth after walking off an edge? You simply teleport back to where you stepped off.Having any choices in the game that could impact the ending or your overall power (like Big Daddies and harvesting/saving Little Sisters)? Don't expect anything even remotely similar, this game has no meaningful choices at all and has a hilariously stupid excuse for it (as well as the previously mentioned teleporting) that comes with the ending.What else do you expect from a game that Levine admitted they had to rewrite 6 months before release to accomodate the ending he came up with? It's hard to go into detail about some things (like the lame explanation for tonics existing) without spoiling the hastily assembled story, but all you need to know is that despite the mildly charming and well crafted environment (one of the few good things in this game), Infinite is a very poor successor to the Bioshock series, and an incredibly mediocre game overall.

												This game. This f*cking game.Well I finished BioShock Infinite a few minutes ago, and I'm still terrified about the game. It's just...okay, let's put it in topics. (Also pardon my english) Story: 10/10  A complete mindf*ck, that leaves you frightened from top to bottom and makes you want to hug your newborn child and cry in the corner. I honestly can't compliment the script enough. Loved the concept of American exceptionalism, perfectly executed. I won't talk much about the lore itself, since I recommend you to actually buy the game and have your own experience from a blank sight. Characters: 9.5/10  I actually managed to laugh with Booker DeWitt, who's extremely charismatic, and a bit of an assh*le. But the spark of the lightbulb here is Elizabeth. Oh boy, Elizabeth. You will fall in love with her, I assure you. She's one of the most charismatic characters I've ever encountered in a videogame. Elizabeth also helps you in-combat, providing Ammunition, Healthpacks and Salts. She can also unlock a few doors and throw you a random coin. It might sound silly, but you'll never get tired from seeing those animations. Speaking of combat... Combat: 8.5/10  I hope you don't hate me for this, but I've never truly been a fan of the usual "BioShock combat style". Yet, if you love it go ahead! The combat itself doesn't change much, but the addition of different guns and different Vigors can and will make you enjoy it. The Vigors are great, and the amount of combos you can do is huge. The enemies are also diversified, and some will even make you wet your pants and die a little on the inside. Adding ziplines, the help of Elizabeth (I'll avoid mentioning that much because of spoilers)  and a ♥♥♥♥ing bird  contributes to make the combat extremely fun. But then again, I'm not a huge fan of such combat. Map Design as a whole: 10/10  Simply astonishing. As an amateur Concept Designer, you wouldn't believe the amount of Screenshots I took. The artstyle is, as always, nice and smooth. I'm not gonna lie, I managed to get lost a few times, exploring stuff and finding random collectibles. I recommend you to..."enter" the game, and feel the whole atmosphere. But oh boy the scenarios.... I mean, it's a f*cking city in the middle of the clouds, if you don't like that, you're weird, yo. Final note: 9.5/10  BioShock Infinite is one of the most well-written and well-executed games I've ever played so far, yet the Combat felt a bit boring for me. The game can be very challenging, specially on 1999 Mode (Don't ask). It's a must-have for players who aren't into BioShock that much, such as myself, and a treasure for BioShock fans. I know a few BioShock millenials didn't like Inifinite because "it doesn't look like BioShock", but come on, dudes.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Bioshock Infinite isn't a horrible game, it isn't anywhere close to being the worst I've ever played, but it highlights the unhealthy mindset game developers have today. This game has received so much praise that it physically pains me, because I know in the back of my mind people with no concept of consumerism are buying into this hype train wreck.Bioshock Infinite has repetitive gunplay with unsatisfying weapons that are better than their successors that appear later in the game when upgraded. It has horrible hostile A.I. that uses no form of logic other than aggressively running into the open and mindlessly attacking the player. There is also a lack of unique enemy types to freshen up the combat, and any uncommon enemy that is in the game can still be killed by simply shooting at them. No enemy types require any form of special strategy or apporach to defeat them, so the unique enemy types serve no purpose, and may as well be normal generic enemies. The vigors lack variety, and often just replace functions that mixed up the gameplay in previous installments of the series. Many of the combat vigors are simply grenades with fancy skins and a tripmine feature. Also the enemy A.I. hardly makes use of vigors, only the flame and crow enemies use any type of Vigor. Splicers in previous Bioshock titles used plasmids very often, and made enemy encounters more varied, plus with vigors taking the same role as plasmids, should they not be a commonly used tool among the citizens of Columbia? The tear feature is extremely under-utilized, and doesn't alter the game environment during combat nearly enough to really keep the experience fresh. So every fight narrows down to shooting at bullet sponge enemies and throwing vigor grenades. Escort missions have always been things players dread, but many games have achieved amazing escort mechanics such as Yoshi's Island, Resident Evil 4 and Ico. Instead of actually trying to be inventive, and making escort mechanics seem less of a chore, Irrational Games decided to remove the gameplay element of escorting Elizabeth from the equation entirely (either to pander to the feminists, or avoid the risk of adding something idiots may think is too hard). Elizabeth is unarmed the entire game in the middle of gunfights, there's no way she can, "Take care of herself," without having a weapon or some line of defense. Despite the enemy's main objective to be capturing Elizabeth, they make no efforts to do so during combat. In Ico and Yoshi's Island, the goal of the enemy faction is to capture your partner, that's why preventing them from being captured is an element to the gameplay. Why is Elizabeth in the game? Answer: To pander to Tumblr psuedo feminists who want capable female characters instead of good gameplay, and neckbeards who want to be together with Elizabeth forever. Elizabeth is a useless friendly A.I. that doesn't aid but rather wastes the players time spawning ammo, health, money or other items (due to the previously mentioned bullet-sponge enemies draining you of your ammo, and the enemies dropping ammo for guns randomly, instead of based on the weapons you are currently using) and stripping control away from the player or clouding the screen with a button prompt to receive the item you could have simply picked up yourself, and in no way takes part in combat. While she can pick locks, there is no reason Booker himself couldn't have been given this abilty during development. Either way, you still have to command her to pick the locks, so you might as well be doing it yourself, her doing it for you also removes the possibility of having lockpicking being an aspect to Infinite's gameplay. The tear ability still requires you to command Elizabeth to utilize it, therefore the ability might as well be Booker's. If Elizabeth had an A.I. that utilized tears based on which would be more advantageous to you at any given time, this would have actually given Elizabeth a purpose in the game; too bad that would require work on Irrational Games's part.Infinite is also highly praised for its atmosphere, but I disagree with this claim.  Attention to detail on the player's part will immediately remove them from the environment they are meant to be immersed in. This game's visuals are praised to be groundbreaking, but only because they used the trite orange-blue contrast everywhere they could instead of the color brown. Level design clashes with the gameplay. Now, the first Bioshock was closterphobic, cramped, tightly packed, consisting of small arenas or hallways. This compliments the more simplistic, arcade-y FPS elements of the game, where you can avoid exposing yourself to many enemies, and reveal yourself to make a quick offensive. In Infinite you have a two weapon limit, so you can't pull out a sniper (you might not have one) and make an offense in the open, you have to approach your enemy, expose yourself, and be forced to take damage. Even the enemy design clashes here, where they'll run at you with melee weapons and be slaughtered by you in the wide open spaces. The melee weapons were useful in Rapture, where enemies could ambush you and get solid hits on you, here it's assanine.Most of this game's "atmosphere" should be credited to fancy skyboxes, and bloom. Whenever I started to take in the environment, something stupid would completely spoil everything. The biggest of all being the first person cutscenes, where the game makes you watch your character do things you didn't command him to do in first person view, the main display mode of the gameplay. When playing a platformer, cutscenes don't play from the stock camera angle, or else you'd be still be in the mindset of trying to control your character, and being surprised to find out that conrol of them has been stripped from you, immediately taking you out of the game.The same rule applies here, the first person view is reserved for the gameplay, so transitions from gameplay to cutscenes are less jarring. Another huge video game sin is where the game presents choices to you through button prompts. These decision making moments aren't presented in the gameplay's format, the gameplay is stopped so you can press a button and watch your decision unfold. One should be prompted to make a decision without being removed from the actual gameplay; the whole Half Life 2 "pick up the can." scenario is a perfect example where you are presented with choice without removing you from the gameplay. The setting of Infinite is nowhere near as compelling as Rapture, where you'd wander the deserted hallways and wonder what life was like before it all fell apart. Instead, Infinite seems to prefer shoving controversial issues like racism or patriotism in, and never actually do anything intellectual with the themes presented.The game's focus on narrative is problematic as well, simply because it takes importance over the game's gameplay; the most important part of any game. People seem to think writing has to be "cerebral" or "deep" to be good, but a simpler story that's charming, horrifying, campy, epic, joyful, or heart-breaking is just as, if not more compelling. Story is something that can be enjoyed on the side. Games shouldn't have to confrom to movies or literature, they are unique in that the player experiences them instead of watching or reading them; the events of the game are happening to you, so you are already invested in the adventure. Video games are about the actions you perform while playing them, the lessons you learn and the the emotions you have while perfoming them, and the sense of accomplishment you experience from overcoming the challenges the game made you face along the way. This game isn't worth your time or money, because it forgets the fact that video games are about the experience of playing them. Anyone willing to look at this game critically will know that buying it is a huge mistake, and a vote for games going further in the wrong direction.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Very pretty game with an interesting story, and my praise ends there. This game oversimplifies the mechanics of the first two BioShock games, removing a lot of features entirely.  Vigors are a dumbed-down version of Plasmids that are not tangential to the plot of the game like Plasmids were to BioShock (though this is cheaply tied together in the last DLC).  Hacking is gone entirely.  Tonics have been replaced with a much smaller variety of equipable clothing.  Vending machines are horrendously expensive.  Skylines are pretty silly for methodically dispatching most enemies at ease.  The game also treats the player with an innovative and never-before-seen regenerating shield on top of their standard health bar.Does not have the same sense of wonder and discovery of the previous games, mostly because Infinite is, dare I say, a completely different genre from the other BioShock games - it's an action FPS, and as far as I am concerned, the only thing that makes it remotely similar to BioShock is a brief tie-in with Rapture, and "BIOSHOCK:" being in the title of the game.I'd recommend it for a $10 Steam sale, not much more than that.  The Burial at Sea DLC brings you back to Rapture in the most awful way possible - playing with the same terrible, console-treated mechanics that you had to deal with in the main campaign of Infinite.  UPDATE 3/25/14:  BoS Episode 2 does a little better in this regard, forcing the player to adopt a stealthier style of play unlike the running and gunning of Infinite and DLC 1.I honestly don't get the critical circlejerk about this game.  It is easily the least fun entry in the series.  For reference, I had played the first and second BioShock games within a period of 72 hours prior to playing Infinite.Update 3/25/14:  Burial at Sea Episode 2 fills a lot of holes and ties a lot of plotlines together, almost to the point where it feels like filling plotholes was the only reason this DLC was created.  Nevertheless, playing as Elizabeth is a lot more interesting than Booker's chapter of the Rapture DLC, and the storyline of the second episode is a lot more important than the first.  Considering that the second DLC offers a "recap" of Booker's DLC, only purchasing Episode 2 is entirely feasible.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												Just an excellent game. Takes about 10-20 hours to play and is a great offline game (why I don't have more hours into this). The story mixes with the actual game and makes a great combo the fighting is never boring due to the combination of guns and vigors (magic). The combat itself is hard and forgiving because of the fall back to a checkpoint style of death while at the same time keeping with the story which every part of this game does perfectly, there's no meta game moments which brings the world in a beautiful way to you, uninterrupted by gameplay. The game is fresh and unique while at the same time familiar and easy to grasp again.The story is that of the best I've played for a long time and without giving away spoilers its one you most likely won't get until the game tells you. It gives you the nice twist you (should) expect and it ties it off, yet in a way that allows for another game after this.=== Complaints: Choices don't matter in this game but they still make the world different and... well its related to the story. There are no puzzles like I expected... aside from The one in the very beginning regarding bells and that... that's a joke. Easy mode is... nothing normal is easy hard is normal and 1999 (konami code) is hard. by that I honestly mean that hard (normal) makes you use your skills and your guns or else, you can also make it through without any back tracking or grinding for money. Easy you could probably use your melee through the entire game. 1999, is the hard mode you expect, requires precision and sometimes may involve an actual use of vigor combinations along with just about anything else. Last is the vigors... they are great and each person has their own favorites, once you find yours you wont stray too far except in some situational use.=== Warnings/Spoiler free tips: If you fancy yourself a seasoned gamer I would recommend entering the konami code at the main menu (where you get an options menu) this will give you a tougher game mode and you don't have to repeat the game in hard / normal / easy. (although I will still play the game on the harder mode so that I can revisit and re analyze the game.) Pay attention. Collect the voice recorders to uncover the full story.Story: 10/10 (WoAh, watch out for that twist)Gameplay: 9/10 (FPS, not very exciting. +Vigors or else it would be 7)Presentation: 10/10 (Good style)Soundtrack: 7/10 (Non memorable, a few snipets of pop culture type of music)Replayability: 5/10 (If you do it will feel like a chore, or that you have been betrayed by the game.)

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
A lighthouse. A man. A city.Irrational's conclusion to the BioShock mythos was widely considered an instant classic upon release and rightly so. The game pays homage to the classics of the late 1990s such as System Shock 2; bringing the excellent design and relevant mechanics of such games to a mostly new audience and era. But unless you've been living under a rock for the past few years, you probably already know this and also have probably played it, so I'll skip the formalities and get right into it. Heads or tails?You are Booker DeWitt, a tortured, former Pinkerton agent, sent by his mysterious employers to the floating city of Columbia, a steampunk, pseudo-Christian dystopia to find the young woman Elizabeth, the city's mysterious idol and supposed heir of Father Comstock, the so-called Prophet and main antagonist. Your goal? To bring them the girl and wipe away the debt. In leading the beloved Lamb of Columbia astray however, your journey as The False Shepherd will take you beyond the blood-soaked city, the ruthless factions vying for control and morality itself as the two descend to where you may not want to go. "We all make choices but in the end, our choices make us."Drawing heavy influence from science fiction and philosophy, BioShock Infinite features a narrative unlike any other, proudly boasting complex themes and a well-written cast characters as the game ultimately plays out as a thought experiment, hinted at from the opening title and the plethora of voxophones, (the audio logs of Columbia), that can be collected. Though it is in the format of a first-person shooter, (with deeply satisfying and fluid gameplay to boot), the world of Infinite is rich and full of life and stands head-and-shoulders above the barrage of military shooters in recent years. The opening sequence is especially memorable and opening the doors to Columbia will certainly be remembered for the breathtaking moment that it is. What you will immediately notice upon playing is just how gorgeous Unreal Engine 3 is, even today. Though the occasional muddy texture would catch my eye or a slight pop-in, as a shameless cinephile, the colour palette really is the gaming equivalent of the Technicolor of classic cinema, i.e. that it is absolutely beautiful to look at.  Now, of course, it would be criminal if I didn't dedicate an entire section to the Sky-Hook. Already featuring the lore-appropriate return of the Plasmid-like Vigors, combat will quickly introduce you to the Sky-Line feature that links the quantum levitation of Columbia's buildings together through a suspended rail system, which you are free to use whenever you like, with a quick magnetised jump on or off. The manual executions with the Sky-Hook are bloody as hell and pretty damn satisfying in the heat of battle.Also complementing general gameplay is your excellent companion, Elizabeth, who might even surpass the likes of Alyx Vance as the greatest companion/sidekick in gaming. Along with her Tear abilities, Elizabeth will frequently collect and toss health kits, salts for your Vigors and money at Booker, repeatedly saving your life, especially on higher difficulties. Furthermore, she'll often have contextual comments or interact with the environment which are always really interesting to hear and I often found myself turning round and walking back to see what she was up to. That is, of course, after Booker was finished stuffing his face with hot dogs and coffee.Over all, you will certainly develop a bond with Elizabeth as Booker begins to find his redemption in her. She is a fascinating and likeable yet tragic character that ultimately feels like a friend to both you and Booker, which makes the ending that much more painful and the plot twists all the more meaningful. Make no mistake, Infinite will pull you into one of the most immersive shooters and mindblowing experiences gaming has even seen and will stay with you long after you've finished playing. In addition to the fairly long campaign, (which you'll undoubtedly go back to for multiple playthroughs even just to pick up on small hints that you missed), and collectibles galore, the DLC released features two sets of content. Clash in the Clouds is a rather enjoyable arcade-like challenge map mode in which you fight off various waves of enemies and complete challenges to progress. I was pleasantly surprised at how enjoyable it is and the mode also includes behind-the-scenes content that you can spend your earnings on to unlock. Far from gimmicky, it is actually quite good. The best addition, however, is the Burial at Sea episodic expansion which brings Booker and Elizabeth into Rapture and the events surrounding the fall of Ryan's underwater utopia in 1959.  The first episode is good, establishing the events of the DLC but it is the second episode where this truly shines, connecting both the original and Infinite in a remarkable and quite emotional experience, well worth the price of the Season Pass. As someone who has followed this franchise since the early days, all the way back to my beloved PS3, words cannot truly express just how great it is to be back in Rapture, realised in all it's true glory in Unreal Engine 3. The respect that Irrational has shown throughout to both the community and the world it has created is remarkable and, though now disbanded, they set a standard for games that all other studios should aspire to. That's not to say that Infinite and it's DLCs are not without flaws however. A divisive criticism since the first game is that the series is often too heavy with exposition and there are some notable plot points left unexplained. The checkpoint feature can be irritating at times, even with the well-executed respawn mechanic. The ability to only wield two weapons at a time can be a pain, especially in large battles and ammo is running low. Booker is no longer the silent, walking death machine that Jack was by the end of the first and 1999 Mode will be sure to remind you of that very quickly. But all of these pale in comparison to the game as a whole. After playing it through again and again, you'll find yourself simply not caring about the few negatives that are noticed. You'll be too busy invested in the top-notch sound design and immensely satisfying gameplay. It is important to note that if you have not played this before then you must avoid all spoilers, even with the third anniversary since release approaching. If you haven't played the first BioShock then I also highly recommend that you check it out. A walkthrough or wiki page does little justice.But I've been rambling on and off for the past few hours now so let's conclude.You'll often hear the words 'essential' or 'masterpiece' be thrown around in the midst of hype and enthusiasm, but BioShock Infinite is one of those rare feats that lives up to itself and achieves what can only be described as true greatness. At the time of writing this review, the entire series is on sale for an absolute steal, but even now it would be worth full price.  It isn't perfect but, in all honesty, when was the last time you played anything that was this good? A work of art and a triumph of gaming as a medium, this is one for gamers and non-gamers alike. Pick it up with the Season Pass as soon as possible.

Posted: January 22, 2014
												This is a game that desperately makes you want to think it's smart when it has no idea what it's talking about and knows jack about it's own subject matter. The combat is limiting and repetitive with a two weapon limit with an expensive as hell upgrade system. The "Vigors" (plasmids with a new coat of paint) all do the same thing with three exceptions: Possess machines for a short period of time (Not the same as hacking from Bioshock 1), charge at enemies with a strong melee attack (comes with a certain upgrade that makes it stupidly overpowered so you'll probably not use anything else), and an ability to catch and reflect bullets (would have been pretty cool if it wasn't given to you at practically the last part of the game), all other Vigors are just the same crowd control effect with a different look. The story doesn't save the game either. In the beginning it tries to send a message about racial equality and revolution but that's thrown away in favor of theories about alternate-dimensions/realities (which don't make any sense at all the second you start thinking about them). Also; why did they feel like they needed to have a twist ending in Infinite? Just because the first game had one? They also did it in Infinite's DLC. Are twist endings now a staple for this series? Do they understand how a twist ending is supposed to work? A twist only works if the audience isn't expecting it, just by making your series the "Series with twist endings in them" you're ruining the surprise because people will be expecting it. That's what made the twist in Bioshock work, the game gave everyone enough hints towards the twist without giving it away; no one was expecting it. In Infinite the twist is not hinted at at all, I played the game twice just to make sure I missed something but any actual hints towards the big reveal were extremely vague. It's only 12 hours long but many areas felt like unnecessary padding. The ending is 20 minutes long and it's whole purpose is to provide an explanation to many of the mysteries in the game, but it fails. Not only are many questions left unanswered, many more questions are raised. They try to explain most mysteries with alternate dimensions and quantum physics which ends up not making any sense.On a sunnier note, Columbia as a setting was pretty cool, but I honestly think this is the only thing the game truly has going for it.Wait a minute that card/10

Posted: August 8, 2016
												It’s no secret that BioShock was regarded as a pretty good game. On the whole it was solid but had some problems – mainly regarding a surplus of pipe puzzles, a few too many fetch quests and a really♥♥♥♥♥♥final boss. BioShock 2 traded those problems for better gameplay on the whole, but spent too much time protecting Little Sisters, and carried the narrative baggage of a million retcons. How convenient that everything that happened before BioShock 2 occured outside of the original.So if BioShock got the story right, and BioShock 2 fixed a lot of the gameplay problems, what happens if you mash them together?You get BioShock: InfiniteThe year is 1912, and you are surprisingly non-silent protaganist, Booker DeWitt. Ex-Pinkerton agent, with a gambling habit, drinking problem, and a lot of debts. When approached with an offer of 'Bring us the Girl, and wipe away the debt', you can't help but take it. At arriving at a Lighthouse, Booker decides to go up to the racist nutters rather than down to the rich nutters.Let’s not kid ourselves, Infinite looks incredible. Rapture’s main aesthetic came from the art-deco style and the murky underwater theme, and BioShock 2 took that and aged it by another decade or so. Ignoring the fact they’re older games, they relied on style and atmosphere more than fidelity of textures. Unfortunately it meant they occurred in identical corridors and big rooms with a few leaks. Infinite has amazing views of a city floating above the sky, and the feel is much different. 1 and 2 were horror games, and you’re being hunted and hounded at every corner. You crawled along dark corridors, scrounging for cakes and bullets, while jumping at shadows of Splicers or a Big Daddy. But in Infinite you can grind a Sky Rail, leap off and smack someone in the face, throw a murder of crows at his buddies, and gun down the survivors in one swift movement.You can only carry 2 weapons at a time, and I think there’s a bit less variety – where there was a multitude of Chemical Throwers, Crossbows, Spear Guns, Rivet Guns, there’s only a couple of weirder weapons, but I found I was using other weapons more often.I was most pleasantly surprised by Elizabeth. I was aware of her story significance, but I didn’t expect her to follow me around, and actually be useful. She scrounges for supplies, throws you ammo and Salts in combat, and you don’t need to protect her! I don’t think I could ask for a much better NPC follower! What were Plasmids are now Vigors, and EVE is now Salts. And there's some great quality of life changes - Vigors have a quick access wheel, and you can have 2 on demand to switch between, and the Salts bar is divided to show how many shots you have left. You can't carry First Aid kits or EVE Hypos like before, but you now have a rechargeable shield, and ther's a lot more items to restore your salts, and the Vigors cost less. Unlike 1 or 2, Vigors felt less useful. I don't think it would be better without them, but they weren't as pivitol in fights to the point I forgot to use them most of the time. Vigors are just kinda...there. Where they were instrumental to Rapture's downfall, Little Sisters and Big Daddies, and in combat, Vigors feel like they're here because they were in the last 2.Much like BioShock 1, I never felt in immediate danger, even when it began getting hectic. Your shield recharges when not being damaged. Salts and most ammo types were fairly common, except for a few of the more powerful or unique weapons. I had Elizabeth to throw salts, ammo and health if it got grim, and while I died a few times, it was never the end of the world, more a minor inconvenience.The final Boss is alright, but Comstock, the main villain, is much less compelling than Andrew Ryan, Frank Fontaine, or even Sofia Lamb. Ryan had some interesting ideas about who’s sweat belonged to who, but he was a pretty smart guy, and wouldn’t allow Comstock to be in charge, considering Comstock is basically racist Santa.BioShock: Infinite is the best story bits of BioShock, the better Gameplay elements of BioShock 2, and some quality-of-life changes. I think it’s the best of the bunch, but if you don’t agree, that’s fine. Not everyone can be right all the time.If I had a Silver Eagle for every time Booker said 'huh', I would buy Columbia.

												This is a very delayed review, and probably not going to interest anyone, so more for my own ego's sake than anything else. That being said, I'll remain spoiler free if you've wandered across this review somehow and haven't played it (you should, its excellent!). Bioshock Infinite takes us from the submerged, suffocating horror of Rapture to the strident, soaring world of Colombia, high above the clouds. The atmosphere and tone is very different, but atmosphere and tone is still very much present in this world. Bioshock is dragged out of the shadows and put into the light. It works, it's a captivating fantasy world which I really enjoyed with its own hooks, but on some level its not "Bioshock" as I immediately associate it with the claustrophobic, maniacal terrors of Rapture. That's not a bad thing courtesy of its magnificent storytelling. There's a good selection of powers and weapons to choose from with a variety of playstyles to select as you please. Having the DLC made the early game feel a little too forgiving however, as you receive a substantial volume of additional resources. The highest difficulty levels present a decent challenge, you have to be moderately conservative with your ammunition and vigors. At no point did I hit a brick wall in my achievement runs of the story, a test but beatable. There is also a challenge mode over several maps, and this is a challenge! Some of the wave missions are pretty demanding and precise, and if you mess them up, you have to start the entire map again and get back to that wave. Be prepared to invest some time if you get the completionist itch. The games strongest component is its storytelling. It's exceptional. Unlike the blank canvas of our Rapture denizens, Booker and Elizabeth are defined characters with distinct personalties, behaviours and voices. They interact heavily with the world around them, and most importantly with each other. There was a really poignant moment where I wandered into a room after a firefight, and found a guitar. Elizabeth began singing as Booker strummed. Spontaneous and incredibly touching. I normally skip such pseudo cutscenes if possible, but I found myself just sitting back and listening. That's good storytelling.They tangibly develop as characters over the course of the game, and you feels its earned and justified. Nothing is more rewarding as a player than when you yell YES! or WHAT! while playing, because you've developed a connection to the characters. There are also the classic Bioshock plot twists. Prepare to dive into the rabbit hole in this one, it gets pretty wild with some clever nods. I loved it. The game also possesses the most wonderfully bittersweet ending, which is worthy of a mention in itself. It makes your second playthrough almost as interesting as your first, as you look for the telltale signs of the set up. And oh boy is it a set up.So the question that rises: is it better than the original Bioshock? Well, in my opinion yes, but for a specific reason. As visceral as the atmosphere and plot twist of Rapture is, the strength of the narration and characterisation in Infinite carries it above it's previous entries, with twists to match those of the first game. It goes on my all time favourites list, and my 100% completion list. 'There's always a lighthouse, a man, a city'
