Posted: December 19, 2013
												After playing this game numerous times (once on Normal, once on 1999) I can safely say it's one of the best stories of all time. The game, however, sucks.Lemmie explain. In the original Bioshock, you had 7 weapons (8 if you include the Camera) that you can carry on you at any given time. This, coupled with the 3 types of ammo for nearly every weapon, allowed you to approach situations and adjust to them as they came. In addition to the interesting weapons, their upgrades were even more fascinating. The ability to freeze somebody by smacking them over the head, then shoot them with fire bullets? Why not?! The possibilites for an interesting combat experience were endless.Bosses in the original also had depth, and were interesting characters. You knew them, you saw what they'd done, you'd heard their words, and agreed with why they must die for you to continue onwards. They also had a habbit for knowing when it was high time to fall over, meaning, after their primary mechanic was exploited, their minutes quickly became numbered, creating a fast paced, difficult, non mundane boss fighting experience. It wasn't just the bosses that died without a ridiculous amount of bullets being pumped into their face, regular enemies didn't take half a nuclear arsenal to bring down, and with good reason; they were just drug heads in t-shirts with the occasional power. Nothing more.My apologies for ranting, but there's a point to this. The reason I mentioned the previous two things in those long drawn out excuses for paragraphs it to show what Infinite is lacking. You can hold a maximum of two weapons (the melee weapon now passively always being attached) and thus decreasing the possible methods of dealing with an issue by an exponentional amount. The upgrades for weapons in Infinite are also a joke, being the standard "Reduced Recoil, Increase Damage, Increase Ammo Capacity". That is boring. This is why I mark off the weapon system as terrible.The second thing to complain about in this game is the combat sections (if they can even be called that). Interesting locations and cool locales taken thrown headfirst into a game of "Who can be the biggest bullet sponge." The enemies act with a reckless disregard for their own safety and recieve no penalty for it because they can take more hits than an IS-2 tank. It's not interesting fighting enemies who can run up to you and tank all the damage and just punch you in the face. The mess of a combat system quickly becomes a chore when you realize who Ken Levine called in when the bosses all called in sick: Handymen, a dude on fire, and a Spooky Scary Ghost. The Handymen might quite possibly be the worst enemy I have ever faced in a game (besides of course the Lopers from Return to Castle Wolfenstein). They're not enemies so much as they're trucks that can fly. They take a ridiculous amount of punishment and just don't die after being hit in the "Weak Spot" at least 20 times by 12 guage slugs. You also need to fight them every 10 or so minutes, so you spend 1/3 of the game playing and about 2/3s fighting these fun champs, who quickly lose appeal after the first encounter. Now onto the good part: The story. Horrible combat aside, Bioshock Infinite is a must buy. The enviroments are diverse and feel real and full of life (until you start shooting but hey then it's full of Up-Till-Recently life), the big enemies/friends you encounter all feel like part of something much bigger than yourself, and the story itself and watching Columbia fall apart is absolutely golden and shouldn't be missed.An 9/10 story coupled with 3/10 gameplay could easily total to a solid 7.5 game. Highly recommend.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												The short: Starts out kinda slow, but it's a great alternate world of the Guilded Age that's achingly beautiful to play in. The shooting mechanic is fun but generic, as is the spellcasting/Vigors powers which is a little dissappointing. This is all secondary towards the story telling which is excellently voiced and written, though pacing in the beginning needs work. There are plot holes (the ending, the mother story thread, etc) and jarring game mechanics (Elizabeth's powers) but nothing preventing you from wanting  to see how this all unveils. For all my quibbles, it's smoothed out with the charming characters and world that Infinite presents.The Long:After 2 hours in to Infinite, I stopped playing this game. I felt bored, and as pretty as the world was presented in this wonderous alternate steam-punk reality of a cotton candied 1910-esque US, it just wasn't enought to keep me interested because I've seen this theme many times in lower detail and quality, and after 10 minutes wondering around, it all felt familiar. The clever plot points were slipped in from early on, but a bit too obvious and/or heavy handedly but at least a good attempt was made.  The gun play is typical, movement was typical, vigors/spells were unique enough but nothing unheard of. And that's when I stopped. The story was being too subtle, especially for a player like me, who wants to see all places presented, thus making the story even slower.  After some nudging from friends, I booted it back on and trudged forward. Once you meet Elizabeth, everything this world and story was building upon started to click. Factions, trials, wonders, backstory, expositories, trageties, horrors, betrayals and tender moments all come at you like a torrential storm surge, each trying to overwhelm the other in waves. Weirdly, through this maelstrom of motivations and hatched plots, the characters and why the world is the way it is, was and/or to be all make some semblance of sense, albeit broken sense if you're not caught up in the spectical/revelation and think about it a bit. The voice acting and dialog is wonderful and believable, there is chemistry between Booker and Elisabeth in their voicing and 3D depictions. You get the sense of balance between tragedy and resilience from Elisabeth, while Booker is definately a man with a past and skin he's not comfortable in anymore.The ending... I'll let you be the judge due to the nature of it. It's definitely you take what you will with it since there really isn't a proper answer besides speculation to be honest. The one the game presents is possible but flawed in my mind, but given the game's title, who am I to really judge? Play it and see if you choose to believe it as it is one of the infinite possibilities.

												Trying to keep this spoiler free.....I both recommend and don't recommend this game. The main issue I had was I got all 3 Bioshocks, never played them until now, so I ran through all 3 of them and Infinite is clearly the weak link and it's really not a Bioshock game.... The first 2 create this atmosphere and semi suspenseful style of gameplay. Creeping around this dark ruined city under the ocean filled with psychos and genetic freaks. You can hear them shouting their crazy phrases and your sitting there wondering "Where the hell are they?!". Every time you encounter a Big Daddy instantly what came to my mind was "Awwww ♥♥♥♥♥t. Here we go!". But in Infinite honestly it was NOTHING like the older games. Your wandering around a bright city killing random soldiers and every day people. Nothings even remotely suspenseful or similar to the first 2 games in any way shape or form. There are no Big roaming sort of bosses like in the first 2 with Big Daddies. It's basically just arena gameplay which I never played Call of Duty but it definitely felt like a generic shooter. Just run into an area and start shooting. You can clearly see they lost any element of suspense with the ridiculous introduction of a damn shield. That completely ruins any aspect of surprise because if someone catches me off guard who cares..... It didn't break through my shield and actually hurt me. What's worse is everythings shared through just generic money. Want to upgrade your powers? Use money..... Want to upgrade that weapon? Use money. Non of the upgrades ever had any actual impact on your weapons appearance like the old games. I found it hillarious using a double chamber revolver shotgun in the old ones that totes electricity through the chambers. This one you can't even hold more than 2 weapons. So why would I even care about these weapons which I'm going to have to keep swapping in and out? I can choose a favorite but this area calls for a Sniper rifle so I have to ditch one of my favorites and oh look Elizabeth tossed me a sniper rifle. I can rant forever but it's just.... .... not Bioshock. The story tries to be clever and almost mirror the events of the first game in a vague sense. But the story is just generic and kind of pretentious.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Recent convo with a dear friend with questionable taste made me want to go a bit more in depth on why I have a problem with this game. Forgive my ranting, derivitive wording, and sloppy editing. Ill probably do something about that at some point in the future.Allosaurus Rex, a youtuber I quite respect, described interactive media as running on parallel lines of narrative devices and player interaction; A games predetermined narrative, the players input into the interactive gamespace, and how those two lines influence each other. If the parallel runs properly, then player input should serve as a narrative device on its own, even in a mechanically linear game. Take for example Hotline Miami, its usage of neon psychedelia and bass thumping combat queues to reinforce the players disconnect from the games violence, and binding it to the player characters own disconnect. The game uses its interactivity to reinforce the narrative and connect the player and character headspaces; The gameplay means the same to the player what the actions its portraying mean to the character. The narrative flows and the gameplay flows with it. The core thematic and narrative concept of Bioshock Infinite, as is traditional of the franchise, is the father-child relationship of the protaganist's filtered through a lens of idealistic extremism, with Randian Objectivism replaced as the focus of satire with colonial American Nationalism. The Father-Child of the story being the player character Booker and his ward Elizabeth. The scripted narrative wants us to feel connected to and ultimately protective of this ward, as the authorities want her back under their control. Protect Elizabeth, that’s the narrative line. The game itself is a linear shooter. Once combat, the gameplay proper, kicks in Elizabeth recedes to the background, immune to damage and only interacting with the player to interrupt the flow of combat to spoon-feed them health and ammo, completely ignored by enemies. That’s the player line. The parallel is obviously not well maintained. A narrative focusing entirely on a cast of two characters and their interactions and how Booker, the vehicle for the player to experience and connect to this story, grows connected to Elizabeth cannot subsist on script alone, something mechanical, something involving the player, needs to be established for that relationship to mean anything. A character as critical to the scripted narrative as Elizabeth cannot be a non-entity in gameplay. Even the excessivity of the violence becomes jarring in the games narrative context. In the original Bioshock the body count made sense within the games world; Jack was engineered to take and dole out damage, and the mentally unstable enemies made suspension of disbelief for their behavior easy, but in Infinite there’s no real logical reason that arguably rational people would be so happy to zerg rush a killing machine like Booker. Going even more basic than that, its a failure. One of the first (ultimately pointless) moral choices the player is confronted with is a pseudo-lynching of an inter-racial couple that the player is forced to participate in. You are given a ball and told to throw it at the couple. At its most basic level, a shooter requires two forms of input: aim and shoot projectiles. So when given a projectile and a target to aim at, of ♥♥♥♥ing course you make the choice with button prompts. Instead of letting the player choose this on their own, potentially letting the setting influence the choice as the pressure of the moment is on them, its reduced to binary hand holding. Without a mechanical factor to bridge the gap between player gameplay and character action, you stop being able to connect to the story as a factor in it and just become a spectator to it. You’re just shooting♥♥♥♥♥♥ and that is a criminal waste of potential in an interactive medium. Its a sloppiness that persists even to the scripted narrative alone. Its heavily praised usage of themes like racial inequality and nationalism are barely present. Compared to real-world racism in real-world America at the time, what goes down in Columbia is tame. Barely any mention of abuse, either physical or verbal, of the black and irish underclass is present in the dialogue. And by the half-way point these ostensibly critical aspects of the game world are thrown out the window for a nonsensical many-worlds plotline that ultimately devolves into the most basic of grandfather paradoxes that uses quantum mechanics as a synonym for magic.Instead of solving the core issues with the concepts presented, like escort missions or enemy AI, the developers over-simplified or cut it out to the detriment of the narrative as a whole. This is a pretty consistent issue; The vigors are a glaring leftover from the Rapture setting. They make no sense in the context of Columbia and its culture, and even in gameplay terms they quickly become redundant to the player, as half of your vigors overlap in use. Even the shooting mechanics end up inconsistent and frustrating. A game with a two weapon limit has no business having a weapon upgrade system. Ammo will never be consistent enough for the player to keep their favored weapons, and the curve of weapon introduction insures that at several critical moments of the game the player is left with un-upgraded weaponry as their only valid option. It limits your arsenal, disrupts its own upgrade system, and leaves the player to deal with its schizophrenic ammo drop system where enemies most of the time drop ammo for weapons that you don’t have and can’t get. TL;DR This game is a pretentious, badly designed mess. For all its praised as being this fresh innovative piece or art, its just another sloppy shooter with a bad story in an industry over-poluted with sloppy shooters with bad stories.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												This game is heralded as the second coming of Jesus by many. Is it?Well, no. It's possibly not onlt one of the most overrated games of all time, but probably one of the most boring AAA first person shooters ever released to boot.The one thing the game has going for it is its phenominal art direction. This is promply ruined by some utterly hillarious character models, props and textures that look like something out of Quake 2. Who needs feet on a cahracter when you can just have flesh coloured matchboxes? Who needs barrels of fruit at a market when you can just have a low resolution texture of fruit put over a polygonal surface? And on top of all this it runs like absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥ even on a relatively beefy rig like mine.Now, what about the gameplay? The grand irony of Bioshock Infinite is that it's heralded as a renaissance from all of those dumb, brainless corridor shooters spat out by big publishers for 12 year old boys, but is in reality unfathomably linear and brainless; more-so than the likes of COD. Enemies are brainless, incompletent bullet sponges who charge toward you like wooden targets for you to effortlessly mow down with your weedy, unsatisfying, royal-free sound effect guns. You might remember the original Bioshock for its ferocious and desperate combat. You won't find that here. You might also remember the brilliant plasmids from Bioshock and the variety they brought to the game. You won't find that here. Well, the plasmids are back (why a society of racial puritans would even think of permanently desecrating their bodies I'll never know (the secret society of crow people being a hillariously bad example which the game never explains)), but I'm not exagerating when I say they all do the exact same thing, just with different, console grade eye candy. One click to stun someone (with an easy instakill if you headshot him), or hold it for a trap (which is useless given the AI). Upgrades all consist of having said effect spread to multiple enemies. You'll probably only ever find yourself using the lightning plasmid. In addition to all of this, instead of actually, say, balance and design their levels properly, the vast majority of the game will consist of you being unable to find ammo or items, but your parter tossing conveniently needed items in your direction every five seconds. And if that isn't bad enough, the game effectively eliminates any and all challenge by having absolutely no penalty for death. Yes, that's right, if you die, you just carry on as usual. You'll lose some money, but as you'll soon find it's utterly worthless as there's nothing you can spend it on that won't be pelted in your direction the second you need it.Yet again, this renaissance of the FPS genre is actually even more casualised and patronising than even the dumbest of COD clones. BUT SERIOUSLY, GUYS! IT'S THE GREATEST GAME EVER MADE!The final thing this game is primarily heralded for is its story. It's an emotional and political tour de force! It sets the standards of storytelling for every game that follows it! Well, I can safely say that's complete and utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.The game is set in what is initially an enthralling and interesting universe of what is essentially Utah; an isolantionist state of religious puritans all brought together in their love for their prophet, of whom live in absolute luxury on the backs of slave labour and show utter disdain for whom they view as racially inferior. Eventually all hell breaks loose as the underclass revolts in a bloody civil war against their opressors. All the while you are sent to save a girl for a mysterious unexplained reason from this heavenly hellhole, of whom you then have to save.The universe the game is set in is intially fascinating and deals with what appear to be some great themes; the metamorphasis of religion and government, a post-modernist interpretation of popular revolutions and their fall from grace from the years of hatred the populace has endured. But this is all quickly abandoned in favour of a multiverse plot. Yes. Alternate universes.You skip universes so much in the main story line that you wonder what the point in even being attached to anything going on is, as you're ultimately abandoning it five minutes after you even hear about it. And when it does go back to the themes it was obviously supposed to cover but forgot at the last minute, it does so in the most juvenile, brain dead, shallow manner.OH MY GOD! THEY'RE GOING TO PELT THAT INTERATIAL COUPLE WITH ROTTEN FRUIT!Well, that's quite literally about as far as the game covers racism. Mississipi Burning, this aint.OH MY GOD! THE LEADER OF THE REVOLUTION WANTS TO KILL A KID FOR NO APPARENT REASON! THE HORROR!Animal Farm this isn't.And to top it all off, it ends in possibly the laziest "OMG SO DEEEEP" ending imaginable. You may remember Bioshock's (mostly) incredible ending/final act plot twist that revealed you to simply be a puppet of the game and those offering you guidance; both a great narrative plot twist, and a brilliant commentary on our own delusions of free will in what is purported to be a free environment where we make our own descisions, and gamer's general tendency to simply do as they're told because they're told to do it. The ending of this game, however, without spoilers, quite literally amounts to "what does doing anything even matter any way? You're just gonna die in the end anyway. ♥♥♥♥ it.". Kind of lazy for the Citizen Kane of FPS.Upon criticising the story, you'll likely be criticised for being too stupid to understand its brilliance, at which point the plot in its entirety will be explained to you. The problem is in proping up this game as a literary masterpiece, the fact that its a convoluted, non-sensical, 12 year old's fanfiction of a wreck of a story the fact that it's confusing, or has serious plot holes, or has the political intruige of the graffiti in the sixth form toilets, it's considered as "ambitious", or "deep", or a "poltiical commentary". It's really not any of those. If you find yourself confused at any point, it's not that the story is too complex for you, it's that it's just poorly written, cobbled together tripe.The other grand irony of this game is the way Elizabeth is fawned over as some revolutionary, amazing female role model for video games. It's become incredibly common for pseudo-intellectual third wave feminism to be considered acceptable in gaming journalism (and as a convenient means of demonizing consumers and protecting massive corporations like the one that published this game), but I can't help but find it ironic that THIS character is an incredible female lead, when she's quite literally  a coddled, ignorant and clueless baby (not my criticism, it's a basic plot point of the game), who requires rescuing from a big prison from a big bad man, regardless of the fact SHE CAN BEND TIME AND SPACE TO HER WILL. Outside of the story she's relegated to a useless bumblbing idiot who throws health potions at you and cowers behind cover in combat, only using her incredible powers when you tell her to. Yep, you've never heard a female character being criticsed for being useless for these reasons before, have you?There's an awful lot wrong with this game, and an awful lot wrong with the people who love it so much. Criticising it will often lead you to be swarmed with gaggles of fanboys telling you to "GO BACK TO COD YOU 12 YEAR OLD!". It's a shame they're so unaware of themselves that they don't realise that they're playing something with worse gameplay, worse graphics, worse story, and worse replayability than even COD.Perhaps worth it for your own curiousity, but it's far from the second coming of Jesus that the gaming press declares it to be, and it's definitely not worth your time or money if you want a game that's actually competent in the areas a game should be competent in.

												I really enjoyed the first 2 Bioshock games and I was looking for this one to see if Bioshock game can still offer really good gameplay, and a great strory with a great setting. This is why I decided to get the game Day 1 and after reading the reviews I got the idea that it would deliver but after playing the game I was really dissapointed with it as I founded to be the weakest Bioshock game in the series. I will start with the good I would say that the game does look really good, does have some nice areas to explore and it does have an interesting story. However, I realised that the story can become a little bit predictible towards the end as the second half of the game really drags on for quite some time, but it does have a really strong beggining and ending. The story is also riddled with plot holes that really don't make sense once you start thinkinh about it. Then theres the gameplay which the weakest. As for a Bioshock game, the shooting is lackluster and as a FPS it is also lackluster. I have just happened to play better FPS games like Crysis 2 and 3 or FarCry 3, whereas Infinte tries way too hard to be a FPS. The vigors are also pretty useless as you will only find yourself using one or two whereas the rest are not that interesting or fun to use, and the same can be said for the weapons. And finally, the vigor and weapon upgrades are also useless as they don't make your guns or vigors that powerful, no matter how many times you upgrade them. Overall I honestly wouldn't recomend buying Bioshock Infinte but instead go for Bioshock 1 and 2 as they are much better games.

												Going to try reviewing this again now that I gave it a fair shot and played it to completion. Long story short: It's still not good in any particular way. It looks and plays rather dated. The game is meanspirited, ugly and not as immersive or intelligent as it likes to pretend it is. Almost everything it does well another game or story does better. Want chaotic shoot and loot gameplay with customizable upgrades with oddly frequent vending machines? Borderlands 2 is all that but non-linear. Want to delve into an immersive dystopia presented in a linear fashion? Try Dishonored. Want trippy pandimensional storytelling that doesn't take itself too seriously? There's a lot of good anime like that, try Steins;Gate. Bioshock Infinite isn't bad but it is mediocre and tiresome, practically presented like a Halo level that threatens to never end. On the plus side, if religious racist political zealots grind your gears the game does serve as a nice anger outlet, but I wouldn't pay more than $15 for the whole thing including DLC. It does have a few neat characers like the Lutece twins that are worth seeing, but they're not enough to salvage the game.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Okay, let me preface this by acknowledging that this game is reasonably well polished, visually impressive and doesn't really contain any content that is particularly offensive.But otherwise this game is incredibly bad, and I am going to lay out why. I think the first thing to do is to comment on the gameplay in comparison with it's forebears, Bioshock and Bioshock 2. This game does not play much like them, yet it plays too much like them. The gameplay was stripped down, with numerous features removed and replaced, and yet no significant work was done to improve the combat. This is a problem because Bioshock combat isn't good, it needs elements to it to give it flavour and strategy, such as hacking, interacting with elements in the environment and making enemies target one another, etc. Infinite only has possession as a function for replacing hacking and mind control but it does this with no flair at all. Hacked turrents/enemies are invincible when they are your ally meaning when the ability runs out you have to deal with them then. The Vigors have almost no narrative reason to be in the game and they lack variety even moreso than the Plasmids from prior games.The weapons are a massive disappointment. Only allowing for two weapons carried massively cuts down on variety of gameplay yet again, their upgrades are not interesting and just change some stats. And you're penalised for not focusing on upgrading only a couple of weapons that you will use all the time. The gunplay is terrible, enemies are bullet sponges making the combat slow and monotonous. I also think that though some areas of the game are very pretty, much of the game takes place in pretty nondescript corridors, or generic open areas.Enemies simply spawn in waves or wander around randomly. They never use tactics, there's only a handful of enemy types. The most interesting part of the game is a fairly standard stealth section and the one "boss" fight it has was a massive slog. At no point is this game every truly fun to play for all the obscene amount of money that clearly went into it. Having said that, the story and characters are somehow even worse. Elizabeth, for whom much of the game centres on, is a lifeless and annoying character whom it's almost impossible to feel any kind of bond with because once you are meant to protect her... you don't. She doesn't exist as far as the game's enemies are concerned, and thus you do not at any point ever protect her. You simply mass murder your way through Columbia whilst she can randomly spawn ammo, health or money for you. Despite her years of confinement, she acts like a ditzy disney princess for most of the game and when things do get more serious, she has a complete personality turn and becomes a relentless and single minded fool who spouts meaningless philosophical nonsense. The ending is incredibly stupid, makes no logical sense and is intensely cruel and evil. In the end this game doesn't manage to be about anything. It has no real message to it, no moral, and no interesting insight into any of it's characters or setting, the setting of Columbia is explored for about an hour at the start and then simply becomes a linear tube for Booker to violently fight through. All of it's characters are stock, reprehensible and pretty much at no point is it possible to sympathise with any of them as they perpetuate a cycle of greed, intolerance and murder. At least in Bioshock Rapture had an ideal built on foundations of intellectualism and free knowledge, Columbia is little more than an idealised floating American city circa 1901. If you're familiar enough with the time period, the game makes very few attempts to use that knowledge for gain, like I've seen in other historical period games like Assassins Creed. And above all, it does not serve any of it's narrative aims by being a poor shooter that doesn't even meet the most basic criteria to be a fun game.

												I used to say that story did not matter in a game if there was a lot to do and a lot of variety. This game proves me wrong. It is an amazing story based game. Highly recommend!Any game that leaves me dropping my controller, just saying "no... no that... no?!" because I was so in to the story makes it worth while. And just as a warning, it will hit your feels a little. haha Awesome game!

content:
Posted: March 23
												"Press F to comfort Elizabeth"I am really on the fence about this game. I liked it overall, but I find it hard to see past it's major flaws. On one hand it's an insanely polished, slick and smooth AAA shooter with amazing visuals. On the other, it's hand-holding, repetitive and casual one with all the tropes and cliches of any shooter made within the last 10 years.The gameplay and shooting are great. It feels awesome shooting enemies, but later on they become bullet sponges to the extreme. The reused environments don't help this at all and I could predict easily when a fight is about to break out. Fighting in the same arena three times so I can progress past some artificial boundry is just dumb. Combat is not challenging at all, there is nearly no penalty for death other than losing a bit of cash. If you die, you're right back into it almost instantaneously (with extra ammo to boot.) With no penalty for death all tension is lost and gunfights become boring. This game needs a harder diffculty with better AI that doesn't just increase enemy health. Playing on hard is barely a challenge. The only time this game shows any semblance of difficulty is when you are tossed into an arena crawling with bullet sponges and no ammo for your weapons. (Which happens more than it should and I doubt that  was fully intended.) A dedicated weapon stand would have helped this issue. Most of my deaths came from handymen who are the biggest bullet sponges of them all and sometimes the game doesn't provide you with the necessary cover/space to evade their cheetah speed attacks. Deaths from these guys always felt cheap to me.(UPDATE:) There is a HUGE diffculty spike in the last hour or so of the game. What the hell? I've never seen anything quite like this. Nine hours of straight easy, then you have to defend an airship from hundreds of attackers. It was quite jarring being to be honest, but a welcome challenge.) It's almost as if the devs are trying to extend the life of the game as far as they can by making the last stage so much more difficult. It sticks out like a sore thumb.The power ups and weapons are fun, but most of them are redundant. You can beat the whole game easily by using the carbine and shock jockey almost exclusively. The sniper rifle is too good when it's fully upgraded. Just shock everyone and shoot them in the head. The weapon upgrades are fine, but I hated how some of them are artificially locked until you progress further, it just feels like another linear element put in to give the player the illusion of choice.This game also suffers from the same thing any game does that tells a linear story. There are far too many scripted parts that take control away from the character. I was stuck in one part for nearly 10 minutes because I wasn't looking at a book the right way to trigger a short cutscene. This game pretty much plays itself when you aren't in one of the many shooting gallerys. Some puzzles or other mechanics would really help to break up the monotony of the endless shooting.The story itself is okay, but nothing really groundbreaking. It's very predictable at times and could really use a better villain with more "screen time." It also seems to drag on way too long, I actually was hoping it would end a couple of times (which is never a good thing.) I'll keep this spoiler free, so I won't go any further. I can see the appeal of this game and there are parts I really liked in it. It seems I've played far too many linear action fps games ike it in the last decade to fully enjoy it. Maybe I am just spoiled. I'd give it a half thumbs up if I could.6.5/10(BY THE WAY, PLEASE FIX THE CRASHING ISSUES IN BIOSHOCK 1 AND 2 REMASTERED PLEASE.)

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												REWRITTEN AS OF MAY 10th, 2014!First off, I have very little that is good to say about this game.Graphics: The graphics are amazing and beautiful, same as the previous Bioshock games at the time of their release, however a beautiful world does not make up for the fact that the rest of this game is bad and it certainly doesn't make up for the fact that the level design is very poor, but I'll get to that later.Gameplay/Combat: This game makes a very poor use of the already old and tired Halo combat mechanics. You get a shield that absorbs damage until it's broken, then you must get behind cover and not get damaged to get your shield recharged. You're also arbitrarily limited to a grand total of two weapons, not counting your melee, which is just a button you hit and not actually selectable. Aside from that, the combat itself is very poor consisting entirely of "shoot these guys." Sometimes you can get Elizebeth to summon an unlimited item cache or an automated turret from an alternate reality, but the turret dies pretty quickly and is pretty much useless, as are the item caches since Elizebeth is a fountain of free items, but I'll get to that later.Story: The story is the most nonsensical convoluted garbage I've ever had the displeasure to endure. I'll try not to spoil anything, but this game makes use of alternate realities as a plot device, which can be really good if done well. Sadly this is not the case. The alternate realities are just a convenient excuse to explain away anything that doesn't make sense, essentially the equivalent of "a wizard did it." The antagonist of the game, Comstock, is an evil, radical, super racist, psychotic religious leader and self-proclaimed prophet who built a flying city whose whole reason for being all that is literally the fact that he got some water poured on him, otherwise he would be a poor, drunk war veteran living in a cheap apartment regretting his actions in the civil war. I am not joking, that is literally the whole reason he's evil. The final moments of the game consist of twenty minutes of exposition because the entire plot is such a tangled mess that this was the only way the writers could attempt to make sense of it. And they failed. Miserably.Elizebeth has these powers to open "tears" or portals to alternate realities and as you jump from reality to reality over and over you lose track of which was the original, but the charcaters don't seem to care at all, despite their entire world changing each time.Level Design: Each and every level in this game consists of two things. You either get a mob arena, or a small enclosed area for some story to happen or poorly written exposition. I've really got nothing else to say here.Characters: I feel all the characters and their motivations are poorly written in this game, especially the antagonist, Comstock, who I've already talked about. Without spoiling anything, Booker is looking to pay off a debt he owes...By bringing them this girl, Elizebeth. I'm sorry, but what kind of good guy takes a woman he doesn't know to some seriously shady people to pay off a debt? Literally all other characters are cardboard cut outs. You've got greedy corprate shill who shows up for five seconds, strong independent black woman who don't need no man and mysterious duo who are mysterious for ♥♥♥♥♥ 'n giggles.Enemies: 90% of the enemies you face in this game are generic soldiers who use guns. Sometimes you will face a pyromaniac, a dude who sends flocks of ravens at you and a giant part mechanical man who is a bit of a tank, he's essentially the replacement for the Big Daddy, but you don't have a choice of fighting him, he just shows up and attacks you. Last, but not least, you have this annoying ghost-like banshee that makes literally no sense, she ressurects anything in the area and constantly sends them after you. Of course the explination for her existing is alternate realities, because of course it is.Graphics: 9/10Gameplay: 2/10Story: 1/10Level Design: 1/10Characters: 2/10Enemies: 1/10Overall (Average based upon above): 2.6/10Don't buy this garbage game, even if it's on sale. Just save yourself the time and the money.

												First, I'll start off and say you don't have to play BioShock 1 and 2 to understand Infinite, as it has it's own story. It might be slightly confusing as to what's going on a few hours in, but it'll kick in. You have to pay attention foremost. Irrational Games went a different route in scenery this time. Although the creepy, dark atmosphere and enemies of Rapture is what made BioShock 1 & 2 so great, you're now in the clouds. And it looks beautiful. Add the soundtrack and it's double that. Gameplay is similar to what you're used to in most types of shooters. You have a array of spells called vigors and you can cast them in combination to get a desired effect. There's weapons too and while you do need to shoot your way out of situations, they're not as exciting as using vigors.Elizabeth is extremely smart and proves to be a very helpful self-dependant ally. So no, don't worry about being a Leon from RE4.Top voice acting, a story that is better than anything Hollywood can ever come up with and fluid gameplay. If you want to play one of the best single players, get Infinite.

Para análise em português, leia mais abaixo.Bioshock Infinite - Review: The Garden of Eden and the Apple of SinFrom an acclaimed franchise, Infinite had a difficult task for the series: Bring new breath to the Bioshock universe, without lose the characteristics that have made fans in the decaying underwater city of Rapture.Infinite leaves the deep water to travel to the skies. Columbia, 1912. An utopia floating in the heavens. A city of peace and harmony as mankind has never seen before. The new Eden, free from sins.And then, it all fell apart. Behind the masks of the holy city, political, religious, philosophical and scientific conflicts corrode that self imposed image. Nothing is what it seems. You're Booker DeWitt, sent to Columbia to rescue the young Elisabeth, held captive since an early age. What secrets the city hides? How important is the girl? And who is she?With a wonderful ambientation, a steampunk reality of the 20s, mixing the culture of this time with a strangely advanced technology. The soundtrack perfectly composes the plot as you cross several different and well made scenarios​​. You can really feel yourself in that place.Open your mind, prepare your heart and come see all the beauties and obscurities of Columbia.  My Personal Score   Fun: 9/10   Gameplay: 9/10   Ambientation: 10/10   History: 10/10   Replayability: 3/10   Multiplayer: 0/10 --Bioshock Infinite - Análise: O Jardim do Éden e a Maçã do PecadoPartindo de uma franquia aclamada, Infinite possuía uma difícil missão para a série: Trazer novo fôlego ao universo de Bioshock, sem perder as características que conquistaram os fãs na decadente cidade submarina de Rapture.Infinite abandona as águas profundas para viajar a céu aberto. Columbia, 1912. Uma utopia flutuando nos céus. Uma cidade de paz e harmonia como a humanidade jamais vira antes. O novo Éden, livre de pecados.E então, tudo desabou. Por trás das máscaras da santa cidade, conflitos políticos, religiosos, filosóficos e científicos corróem esta imagem que se impõe. Nada é o que parece. Você é Booker DeWitt, enviado a Columbia para resgatar a jovem Elisabeth, mantida em cativeiro desde tenra idade. Quais segredos escondem a cidade? Qual a importância da menina? E quem é ela?Com uma ambientação maravilhosa, uma realidade steampunk dos anos 20 mistura a cultura da época com uma tecnologia estranhamente avançada. A trilha sonora compõe perfeitamente a trama, enquanto vocês cruza diversos cenários diferentes e bem feitos. É possível realmente se sentir no local.Abra sua mente, prepare seu coração e venha conhecer todas as belezas e obscuridades de Columbia.  Minhas Notas Pessoais   Diversão: 9/10   Gameplay: 9/10   Ambientação: 10/10   História: 10/10   Rejogabilidade: 3/10   Multiplayer: 0/10

Posted: July 24, 2014
												This isn't a video game, this is a piece of artwork (on par with other moving paintings like Shadow of the Colossus) that you have the privilege of experiencing.  The story and characters will transport you to another place entirely, a city in the clouds where the idea of white, American, Christian, capitalist culture has been turned into what can only be described as a haunting cult. Don't go into this game expecting to find the greatest shooting mechanics ever created; that isn't what it's about (which isn't to say the shooting and fighting isn't fantastic).  It's about the immersion from the brilliantly crafted storyline and beautiful writing.  This is one of those rare games where you truly sympathize and connect with the characters, especially Elizabeth - they feel alive, largely in due to the amazing voice acting.  Honestly,  if this had been written as a novel as opposed to a video game, it would be a modern classic.I never thought any video game could come close to making me re-live the emotion I first felt when playing Ocarina of Time (my favorite title ever) but this comes extremely close.  If Ocarina is a 10, this is a 9.99999999999999999~.Play the game.  Wipe away the debt.

												After playing this game I'm wondering if there is a universe in which I didn't like it. The answer is probably NOT, because this is one of the most ridiculously beautiful game I've ever played.Does it have amazing graphics? Yes, it does.Does it have amazing voice acting? Yes, it does.Does it have the most realistic, fun and talented female companion of all time? Yes, it does.Does it have great variety of combat scenarios? Yes, it does.Does it have a complex, incredibly beautiful, engaging, feelingful storyline? The tears of sadness and joy in my face says so.Does it have a satisfying ending? F*CK YEAH IT DOES!Sadly, I don't have enough knowledge of the English language to come up with any more adjectives to rate this game. This isn't even a game, it's a work of art. Those who say that games can't have the same impact as movies or books ARE F. STUPID. And those who say this game in particular does not have at least one of the best storylines ever didn't understand it. I guarantee it! Read a guide online and be amazed.I rate it 10/10 for the story. I'll add another 3 for combat mechanics, 2 for graphics and scenery, and 2 more for the game longevity. So, 17/10.Oh wait, did I mention Elizabeth? The companion? She's great, oh so great, that I think I'll add OVER 9000 points because of her. Yes, that sounds fine.So yeah... my final rating for this game is an astounding OVER 9000/10. SHUT UP, the king can do as he likes!I also loved the Rapture reference from Bioshock 1. One more point for that.  Play this game. PLAY IT.Did I mention how great this story is?

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												BioShock Infinite is an artistic masterpiece. Beautiful, suspenseful, and haunting at times; it captures a blending of history and myth to create something both wonderfully unique and familiar. Elizabeth is one of the best characters to ever appear in a game and the world is beautiful.Story: 10/10 As we all come to expect from Irrational, the plot of this game is bursting with rich parallels, powerful emotional imagery and an ending (brilliantly foreshadowed throughout) that will leave you both satisfied and begging for more. Ambiance: 10/10 This is where the game really shines. Each set-piece alone could be a work of art, each architectural blend, each cultural costume. All of the visual splendor mixed together with a score that perfectly juxtaposes the glamor and grit of what Columbia represents. Gamplay: 10/10 I expected a rich story and beautiful visuals/music, what I did not expect was game-play (particularly combat) that surpassed Irrationals previous games in terms of enjoyment and dynamic action. This game takes everything that we loved from previous BioShock games and adds a whole new level of tactical planning and on the fly improvisation. Each combat area is a stage set for a brilliant play, each enemy adding new challenge, each weapon a chance to master. Never has combat been so challenging and satisfying in a BioShock game.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												This isn't a video game, this is a piece of artwork (on par with other moving paintings like Shadow of the Colossus) that you have the privilege of experiencing.  The story and characters will transport you to another place entirely, a city in the clouds where the idea of white, American, Christian, capitalist culture has been turned into what can only be described as a haunting cult. Don't go into this game expecting to find the greatest shooting mechanics ever created; that isn't what it's about (which isn't to say the shooting and fighting isn't fantastic).  It's about the immersion from the brilliantly crafted storyline and beautiful writing.  This is one of those rare games where you truly sympathize and connect with the characters, especially Elizabeth - they feel alive, largely in due to the amazing voice acting.  Honestly,  if this had been written as a novel as opposed to a video game, it would be a modern classic.I never thought any video game could come close to making me re-live the emotion I first felt when playing Ocarina of Time (my favorite title ever) but this comes extremely close.  If Ocarina is a 10, this is a 9.99999999999999999~.Play the game.  Wipe away the debt.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												I love this game and strongly dislike shooters. Yes, it’s a shooter, and there is a lot of shooting, but this game is more about the story and less about the shooting. The story is absolutely engrossing. The game world pulls you in and makes you want to know more and more about the city of Columbia. I highly recommend taking your time and listening and viewing all that collectibles. The collectible really do a good job of fleshing out the city’s history and the history of its main citizens. The city is fully realized and I could spend hours walking through it and taking it all in. The character of the city is beautiful at first. Then as you start listening more and more to the chatter of the citizens and you start reading the billboards and advertisements you soon realize this city is not the Eden you thought.While the city of Columbia as a character is completely fascinating, Elizabeth, your female partner which the entire story hinges on, is even more interesting. She exudes innocence, naivety, curiosity, empathy, adventure, courageousness, bravery, and sadness. I’ve never played a game that caused me to feel guilty and sadness towards a character. Elizabeth takes you on an emotional roller coaster that I never wanted to end.When the ride was over, and the last piano key was struck, I just sat in my chair, staring at my monitor. The emotional tug of the game had left me immobile and speechless. I wanted more time with these characters. I didn't want the game to end. I wanted to know more about the city, about Comstock, about Booker, and about Elizabeth. I didn't want this to be the end.As I sat there, mindlessly watching the credits roll by, and listening as the various music played I replayed the entire game in my head. Then, during the credits you get to watch the voice actors sing the song, Will the Circle Be Unbroken?. I listened to the words; I then understood what the song meant and how it relates to the game and the ending.After all is said-and-done, no game I have ever played has caused in me such an emotional reaction. No game has made me want to save a character more and no game has made me sit and stare off into space when it was over. The ending hit me like the LOST series finale. It's over......and I'm sad that it is.

												After playing this game I'm wondering if there is a universe in which I didn't like it. The answer is probably NOT, because this is one of the most ridiculously beautiful game I've ever played.Does it have amazing graphics? Yes, it does.Does it have amazing voice acting? Yes, it does.Does it have the most realistic, fun and talented female companion of all time? Yes, it does.Does it have great variety of combat scenarios? Yes, it does.Does it have a complex, incredibly beautiful, engaging, feelingful storyline? The tears of sadness and joy in my face says so.Does it have a satisfying ending? F*CK YEAH IT DOES!Sadly, I don't have enough knowledge of the English language to come up with any more adjectives to rate this game. This isn't even a game, it's a work of art. Those who say that games can't have the same impact as movies or books ARE F. STUPID. And those who say this game in particular does not have at least one of the best storylines ever didn't understand it. I guarantee it! Read a guide online and be amazed.I rate it 10/10 for the story. I'll add another 3 for combat mechanics, 2 for graphics and scenery, and 2 more for the game longevity. So, 17/10.Oh wait, did I mention Elizabeth? The companion? She's great, oh so great, that I think I'll add OVER 9000 points because of her. Yes, that sounds fine.So yeah... my final rating for this game is an astounding OVER 9000/10. SHUT UP, the king can do as he likes!I also loved the Rapture reference from Bioshock 1. One more point for that.  Play this game. PLAY IT.Did I mention how great this story is?

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Gladius Dei or "same, same but different!"Bioshock Infinite is basically a revamped version of BS2 in a new environment. The gameplay is superior over the other episodes and much better balanced. The story is nearly as good as the first one. It cares for the female player, got lotsa eye-candy and has the highest grade of replayability compared to the other parts. In my opinion, balancing story and gameplay, the best of all 3 Bioshock games. If you liked the others, you will also like this one. At best, you played just BS1 and not the 2nd part beforehand (unless you wanna play all 3).storyThough BS2 had not a bad story, the Would you kindly? moment was missing. Now, you got a repackaged BS2 story which takes care of that. It is somewhat unrelated to the other episodes and you could use it as a starter to the Bioshock world, though due to graphics and gameplay, I advise against it.It definitely tries to get the girls to the consoles as in a slightly female colour scheme, a female hero w/o mega♥♥♥♥♥♥nor skin tight leather... and to top that up, even a change of hair dressing is included! ;P That said, there is enough blood, dirt and gore and Bioshock manages once more to combine high morals with bloodiest violence and beautiful sceneries.A lot has been recycled from BS2, though: It feels a bit like the Syren Alley level and its objective being a whole game combined with the Eleanor meta story. In Ryan's Amusements you had to get a Plasmid inside a propaganda amusement park for kids in order to continue a journey on a train. In Soldier's Field the difference is only that Plasmids are called Vigors and that you continue your journey in a Gondola. Besides an obstacle blocks your carriage and you have to get the Plasmid/Vigor inside a children's propaganda theme park. Fink and his stage reminded me a bit of The Great Alexander - There are many moments which feel like BS2.gameplayUsed to be the biggest pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥on its predecessors, but the Bioshock team seems to learn by trial and error. Each part gets better gameplay-wise and now, the mindless spawning and many shortcomings of BS1 and BS2 are gone.The gameplay is much better balanced due to:* "Killer"-Plasmids are mostly gone in the main game (like Winter Blast for example).* Plasmids are generally better balanced and thus less powerful than before.* Adam is gone as character building source it is now "all about money". Since corpses contain money, the infinite spawning of enemies is gone in BS Infinite.* the marvellous Green Arrow which gives you directions on demand!  No more "Should I turn the quest arrow on or off?" A+++* The research system is gone and nobody will miss it!* Sadly, the mini-games are gone, too. Elizabeth lockpicks the doors, safes and chests for you now.* Enemies and gear are revamped but the same: Houdinis, now called Zealots, are fewer but tougher. Handymen are basically extra fiery Brute Splicers and the Rumbler returns in a downgraded version as Beasts; there is even a  Mark Meltzer moment. Insect Swarm is also far less powerful now and replaced by Murder of Crows - which is a good thing, since Insect Swarm and Winter Blast was all you needed, even on the most difficult settings.* generally, the gameplay is more stream-lined, though there are more collectibles.* Negative: More CoD-like in the sense of a less tactical approach and the shortage of resources.* Many tutorial elements in the game are too short or simply missing. Vigor Combos for example, though there would have been enough chance for it on some fair stand. * The skyline could be better integrated into the gameplay, but as mentioned below, it seems to be technically the most critical part.graphics, bugs & CoRan it on Win7 64bit with a Geforce GTX760 on highest settings w/o problems. Only major bugs I encountered was on the skyline, there I got stuck under certain circumstances. Also, the only minor bug I am aware of is as well connected to the skyline. It let's Liz circle the skyline for hours, once I am already off - but it doesn't hinder progress and at some stage she is back.Unfair to compare graphics, since I played both old parts on XP, but lotsa eye-candy indeed. And as I found just far more "picturesque". Burial at SeaHaven't played it as of yet....Btw: Si tacuisses... !Hm, a game that costs soo much money to produce and is so in love with detail, ridicules itself by misuse of professionell knowledge?The first steps into Columbia makes you believe you entered an alternate world of idiots: * Gladium is like clavem an Accusative version of the words gladius,-i and clavis,-e.* 2 Lockpicks will never open a lock, but inserting a tension wrench[/i] and a lockpick will. Besides but important: Locks don't get damaged by picking (but picking can be detected forensicly).

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Not everyone was entirely happy or impressed with where the developers chose to take this third entry in the almost-legendary Bioshock series, but in my opinion the decisions made were mostly the "right" ones.  MOSTLY.      Let me just say straight up - and this may well be an opinion subject to change given that I've played the first two games twice and this one but once - that this is probably my "least favourite" of the three games.  This is a purely personal thing:  I am, on the whole, more a fan of "horror" than other fantasy-related genres, and while the first two games were perhaps not strictly of said genre, they certainly leaned more heavily toward that side of things than this latest instalment does.     Which brings us to the first two significant decisions made during the development of this game:  first up, the change of setting from ruined, claustrophobic underwater city to a city in the clouds rapidly HEADED towards downfall; and secondly, the shifting of the main "enemy" type from insane, physically-deformed mutants (some with the rough equivalent of supernatural powers) to well-armed soldiers and revolutionaries caught in a power-struggle to either defend or bring down the mad "prophet" who founded their would-be utopia.     It's obviously a matter of purely personal taste which of these two "tones" one prefers...but in spite of myself generally favouring the former, I do have to say that they really COULD NOT have gotten away with a third game set in the city of Rapture.  So all things considered, I'm conceding that they probably made the "right" decision.  It was due time to change things up a little, and they've done so in a way which is equal parts "obvious" (moving from a city under the sea to a city in the clouds) and "inspired" (they really could have just done another POST-apocalyptic scenario, but instead chose to tell an entirely different story...and good for them)!    This said, the actual GAMEPLAY is remarkably similar to the earlier games, with one important exception:  they've replaced a bunch of lovable (if slightly creepy) little girls with a single grown woman, and this is arguably where things become most different.  Say goodbye to the oddly endearing task of liberating and/or baby-sitting "Little Sisters", and say hello to a sassy, would-be "romantic" interest who's constantly torn between despising our (anti-) hero for his "brute"-like behaviour, and being strangely attracted to him for, well, basically the same reasons (hmmph...women)!     Not only does this change the tone of the piece quite significantly - call me a sap and/or misogynist, but I was actually quite moved by all the "take care of the cute little gals" antics of parts 1 and 2 - but in effect also makes this a much more linear experience than the first two games. Our only reason to "backtrack" now is to get more goodies hidden behind doors which our female companion can helpfully pick the locks of, rather than the far more involved task of harvesting "ADAM" required in the first two games.     In short, we've lost a bit of tiny bit of strategizing along the way, in favour of a more straight-forwardly arcade-y experience of moving from location to location and killing lots of things and picking up a bunch of stuff.  Again...personal preference will decide for the individual whether this is a good or bad thing.  I myself found it all a bit repetitive and "draggy" towards the end, and found myself mainly using only two of the eight "vigors"/special powers on offer, but y'know...that's just me.      Whichever way you look at it, this is still a pretty smart, classy game.  It boasts some of the best graphics in video game history (think an ultraviolent "Disney" cartoon, and you're getting warm), and a pretty interesting storyline to boot (though I gotta say, the people who made such a huge fuss over the supposedly "controversial" ending...you people really need to read more, or at the very least stop watching all those ♥♥♥♥ing Michael Bay and Marvel movies, 'cause it really wasn't THAT much of a mind-blowing revelation at the end).     There's every chance I'll even find myself utterly adoring it the second time around, but right now...frankly, I'm a little "spectacular"-ed out.  Which is a way of saying this game isn't exactly anyone's definition of "subtle", so if that's what you're looking for...I dunno, maybe try Gone Home or something instead.  But if it's slam-bang action and jaw-dropping scenery you want, with just a pinch of cleverness and mind-♥♥♥♥ing thrown into the narration to add a bit of spice, there's not much risk of finding disappointment here.  Verdict: 9/10.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												I played this game and loved it, but I am not going to pretend it was perfect. While it's considered a game, the game parts are above-avarage at best. I'll go over it.Story: You are Looker DeWitt, a man hired to find a certain girl in the lands of columbia for a price. That's how it starts at least. Throughout the story you meet Elizabeth, and unlike most followers in games, she isn't useless and is actually rather charming. The story shows their tale... tales... I don't even know how to describe it because the ending is a mind breaker, but i won't spoil it. Either way you'll see them learn and progress. Especially Elizabeth changes over time. Starting as an innocent lady and eventually becoming a badass. The story is easily the strongest part of the game, even if it's all over the place at times due to the cheap way of "Alternate Timelines/Dimensions" yada yada. But in this game it was actually implemented in a very good way. For story alone I would recommend the game. But I'm not done yet.Graphics:The graphics are stellar. Columbia is really beautiful and other areas in the game are aswell, but in a different way. You can see how bad something is going just by looking around in later areas and it's a really beautiful but also a kind of sad place at times. The game is beautiful, no doubt about it.Racism?:Yeah yeah you heard it from everyone, hur durr racist game. Seriously, don't even pretend racism doesn't exist. In fact, I would say it's a strong point of the game. Gives you more of a reason to hate the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in charge. So those who complain about this game being racist, IT'S FOR A REASON.Audio design:The music in areas really add to the atmosphere of the game. Both for the darker and lighter places in Bioshock infinite, the music makes the areas really stand out. Sound effects are pretty good aswell. I would say the gun sound effects COULD be better, but it's not bad. It's pretty good. Other than that the sound in the game is great! The voice acting is done extremely well and the actors really helped you get attached to eachother and the emotions the characters felt were well translated by the voice actors.Gameplay:Look. Like I said. The Gameplay is above avarage at best. You have two spots for guns. While this could be used for strategy, there is no reason to. It's clear which guns are better for you and it's not like you're running out of ammo anytime soon. Or health for that matter, as Elizabeth keeps throwing health pickups, ammo pickups and salt (explaining that later) pickups. The only time you ever really get in trouble is when Elizabeth isn't there. And that's a really small portion of the game. Elizabeth kinda feels overpowered, but either way everything around you contains health, ammo and salt too. Seriously, if you have elizabeth with you, shoot away! You won't run out of ammo, at least I didnt.You also have these vigors (or plasmids). They are really fun to use I'll admit. But besides watching crows kill people or lighting people on fire, there is no reason to use it. The upgrades for the vigors and weapons arent anything to be excited about either. Then there is the skylines... A neat feature. But really not that useful for anything other than escaping some mad men. Good luck aiming when you're turning around a corner on the skyline. Now, is Bioshock Infintie worth the price tag?... I'll be honest, it is if you care about story and graphics. If you want it purely for gameplay, then please wait for when it's a decent price, like on sales. But the price tag now is pretty appropriate for this game. It's not the best game ever, but it's damn good at what it wants to do. Create an atmospheric experience with excellent story and graphics. Sadly, they sacrificed Gameplay for it, but it's definitely something anyone must experience. Just wait untill the price is appropriate for you, and then get it.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												If you had not followed this games hype, and you had not played Bioshock 1 & 2, then this game is fantastic, buy it, get sucked into the narrative.If not?Then you're like me. I wanted to like this game, I really did. But the issues begin when the game was first announced. All the ads, all the hype for it went into overdrive, even if you avoided it, it was there in a wave that would easily wash over you. When the game was first announced, it really seemed as if it would be a succesor to the game famous for its storyline, setting, and twists. When it was announced, the game was nothing like it is now. And if you followed just how they set up the game before it was released, all the hype of Handymen and Boys of Silence, then you would be kicked in the groin as you realize the two enemies are thrown into the final version of the game as little more than an afterthought. The game boasted its many possible choices, all the good and bad things you could do with your magical partner in crime...But when it came down to it, not a single choice you made mattered five seconds after making it. Sure, Bioshock 1 & 2 were similar, the Little Sisters gave you mana, but the game actually changed depending on those decisions. The Little Sisters would tremble in fear of the infamous Boogieman who had slaughtered every child he had gotten his topsider hands on, or the Bad Daddy who had no heart unto that steel carapace. And on those lines, Bioshock Infinite took the concept of Vigors/Plasmids and ruined it. It became a gimic, where every single power ultimately did the same thing. The only difference was that an enemy who was obviously well versed with that power was immune. The vigors were almost useless throughout the game, their only use being to incapacitate enemies for short periods of time so you could focus on the much better developed guns. No longer could you work so hard at sacrificing power for quite some time so you could gain a power that earns you a temporary but nigh-invulnerable protector, that would simply be too easy wouldn't it? Enemies you hypnotize seem to lose their effectiveness by at least half, moving in sluggish hazes as compared to the devoutly loyal you could possess in this games predecesors. And on my final point, one of my biggest issues with Bioshock Infinite was its take on the Big Daddy. Songbird. A grotesque beast trapped within confines of leather and metal. The game constantly boasts its strength, unmatched and undefeated. And for a while, running into the beast was exhilerating, I could see why people simply loved the single, giant creature that replaced the numerous abominations of Rapture.  And then, one day, I came upon a realization that ruined it for me.Songbird was not a threat.Various scenes have you running from Songbird, trying to prepare for its arrival, or simply trying to thwart the beast. But at any point where the creature confronts you, at any point where you may be challenged, you lose control of the character. You watch a cutscene of Booker somehow escaping the beast, and then going on to have Elizabeth rant about how powerful Songbird was. There is a type of horror in creatures in a sense of "show, don't tell," and it feels like the makers of this game tried a version of that. Thing is, the illusion of the threat and horror is simply too thin.This is an amazing game, believe me. It simply is not the perfect work of art people claim it to be.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												I've never really had a favourite game. Favourite book? Yes, Favourite film? Yes. But never a game, there were so many great ones that I couldn't separate. At least until I played Bioshock Infinite & it took my Number 1 slot by a mile! In fact, before I would put the game on such a pedestall, I played it again within 6 months. I actually enjoyed it even more than the first time.I was gifted Biosock 1 by a friend as I like immersive, story driven games. Not only was the plot engaging & inovative, & the gameplay interesting & open to different styles, the game was a set in a fabulously good looking location. However, it built itself up so well, that a boss fight wasn't enough to do the story justice & I was left wishing they'd actually finished the plot, instead of simply ending the game. Bioshock 2 was more of the same, adding lots to the universe but resolving little. A good game on it's own, but didin't really do anything new.I expected more of the same from Bioshock Infinite, but I'm happy to say, I was left utterly, stupidly & soundly corrected.Bioshock Infinite takes what made Bioshock 1 & 2 great while learning the lessons of the earlier game & in the process did something I have never seen in a game: make an NPC the lead character...The game is set in 1912, in a cloud city called Columbia, which is another beautiful setting to play out the story, with a clever rail system you can travel along & dive-bomb onto enemies or gun them down from the rail. Either way, you can become death from above & is a brilliant addition & makes Columbia feel like it is in the air. And yes, you can fall to your death. Or make an enemy fall to their death. Great fun.The guns are period weapons, & like all Bioshock games, they can be upgraded for bigger clips, reduced recoil, bigger hitting power etc, but unlike Bioshock 1, the guns dont change appearances. Previously, guns have gained mechaincal devices that are doing the job of the upgrade. It feels like a step backwards, but it's a small gripe & one of the few I can find. Ammo can become scarce for certain weapons as you go through the game, but as before, there are vending machines dishing out health & ammo, so if you have the money, you can keep your guns stocked. You also have Vigours; abilities that let you shoot electric bots or fireballs, or even flocks of deadly crows. You need Salt to 'power' these & is picked up or purchased like ammo. Known as Plasmids in Bioshock 1 & 2. They give great tactical flexibility, you can use them or not, the game leaves it up to you. The variety is nice & I found I used all the different Vigours more often than Plasmids, although I did stick to combos that worked with the type of weapons I choose.The plot is layered really nicely. If you just want to shoot stuff, then there is a fairly simple "get this girl & bring her back" plot to enjoy, with a fairly relentless & fanatical antagonist (Comstock) pursuing you. However, delve deeper & there are ideas & commentaries on equality, racism, revolutionaries, religion, fanaticism, science, morality & even time travel. There are so many levels to engage on & this helps to hide the fact that Bioshock Infinite is a pretty stright, linear FPS, no sandboxing here my friend, but this helps pacing so well that, trust me, you won't notice it at all. On my second play through, even knowing the plot, I felt like I got more involved in the game as I know the characters & their stories.On the characters, there are the Letuce twins, who provide some comedic & satarical relief, hiding the fact they are actually important components of the story, Comtock; a fanatical, charismatic leader who after a few taunts at your character, you really want to beat. Your character, a guy called Booker De Witt & I should tell you, he is a complete a*rehole. In fact, 1st play through, I almost wanted him to end up the bad guy & get what he deserves! You character is pretty unlikable throughout, although he does develop into a better man towards the end, but he remains a perfect anti-hero because he never really becomes the hero. The other thing to say about Booker is that the story of Bishock Infintite is NOT primarily about him. Of course, he is a major character in the story, as is Comstock, but the story is about an NPC, the girl you are sent to Columbia to recover; Elizibeth. Elizabeth is one of my truly favourite things about Bioshock Infinite in that the decision to make her the main character & keep her with the player throughout was made early & stuck to relentlessly by Irrational Games. Even when it seemed impossible to make her work the way they wanted her too, Irrational stuck at it. And this tenacity makes Bioshock Infinite stand head & shoulders above all but a handfull of games, of any type.During combat, Elizabeth ducks out of the way, keeping out of the line of fire, but chucking you ammo, health & salt occasionally, but you can't rely on this all of the time as the supply varies throughout the game. Once the combat ends, she emerges safe & sound. Occasionally, when she's ahead of you, she is in enemy sight, but they ignore her but open fire instantly when you're spotted. Again, a slight flaw, but it happens on few occasions so is one I'm happy to forgive. This means, the rest of the time, she can make conversation with Booker, grow as a character & give the player a chance to invest in the story that unfolds around you both. She has a wonderful, stubborn niavity that is steady worn down through the game & she matures into a much 'older' version of herself, which is reflected as her clothes get damaged & torn, she cuts her hair & she picks up injuries at set pieces.For some reason, my first thought when I saw her was that she reminded me of Belle from Disney's Beuty & The Beast, both in her initial character, dress & hair syle, but it may just be me. Either way, Elizabeth is a fantastic innovation both as a character to grow, develop & revolve a plot around & as a technical acheviement of making her function properly through what is occasionally a frantic FPS.I mentioned Irrational learning lessons from the previous 2 Bioshock's & the biggest is how to end a plot, which is not finished by a boss fight & a cut-scene. There is a boss fight, a fairly tough one, but after that, there is about 20mins of 'game' left as you are taken through the plot, tying up all the strings that have been laid down into a fabulous bundle that left me really, really wanting more, but utterly satisied all the same. There's no combat, very few choices the player needs to make, but I was so enthralled I barely noticed 1st time around. It was only when I reached the actual end, when the story was finally unravelled& revealled that I noticed I'd finished the FPS bit some time ago. It wasn't quite the ultimate hairs-standing-on-end, but a few stood up for me, even the second time around.Basically, if you like immersive, story driven games with good characters & a beautiful setting to play it all out in, then Bioshock Infinite is a game you absolutely MUST play, as it is one of the best. No argument. So go buy it at what ever price it's at & play it.I cannot put into words how highly I recommend Bioshock Infinite.

Posted: March 21, 2014
												BioShock Infinite is a really fun game with a very unique story. If you haven't played this game yet but intend to, do yourself a favor and DO NOT spoil the twist ending for youself. Like any game, it has its imperfections: I feel like the new Health/Salts system is nowhere as good as the system in the first BioShock Health/Eve system. Here, instead of having several health kits and even hypos on you that allow you to refresh your health and eve in a battle, you need to actively look for those items in your environment which can often be a hassle because the salts are so scarce. While under different circumstances this system might have worked, in BioShock Infinite it just becomes annoying after a while. Another qualm that I have is the Vigors themselves. While each of the vigors is unique and can be combo'd with another vigor, most of the vigors do essentially the same thing: they disable enemies in an area for a few seconds and deal some damage. There are some exceptions but ultimately out of the entire arsenal of vigors you end up just going around using one of them to do all the work. Unlike BioShock 1 and 2, the storyline is now much more linear and while some sandbox elements were added such as a couple of secret locations, they're barely noticeable. The Haevy Hitters, which are the equivalents of the Big Daddies from previous games have been reduced from enemies that you need to carefully plan your fights with to simple bullet sponges. Ultimately, despite these flaws the game is still very fun and enjoyable, has a great story and I do recommend, but it doesn't live up to the original BioShock.
