content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Being a huge fan of BioShock 1 and 2, I was excited about this game coming out. For months I avoided everything the /r/gaming ♥♥♥♥♥ had to say about it, avoided spoilers, avoided gameplay videos. Anything to just not spoil what I assumed would be the story behind the awesomeness that was the first two games.I was wrong. So very wrong. This game is terrible. It's a bigger piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥than Assassin's Creed 3. The entire game is comprised of the dev team sucking each other's♥♥♥♥♥♥♥for 6-12 hours while moaning "mmmmm fatalism nnnngggggggg" over and over. The combat is garbage - you can overpower everything easily without having to worry about things like needing to find all the weapons. The plasmids are pointless. Other than the game forcing you to use some of them to advance the storyline, you can just pick the one you like best and annihilate everything. Or you know, abuse the Tears to just cheese turrets and the like. They respawn, so if yours dies, just hop up on the sky rail and wait it out, then re-Tear them. Or do like I do in all games - walk the ♥♥♥♥ up to mobs, beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them melee style, and laugh as you plunder the soggy remains of their bodies for cash and food. Let's talk about food for a minute. It's everywhere in this city. People just carry tons of it in their pockets. One guy had a pineapple in his pocket. Seriously. A pineapple. Could you tell from looking at him that he was sporting such an epic bulge? No. And it's not like he had some unique brand of pants that enabled him to stuff a whole pineapple in there - they were the same pants everyone else had. Good news for guys hung like a moose, and good news for guys who don't believe in carrying grocery bags.The gameworld is pretty, as long as you don't look at things like the very flat grass and plant life. There's a lot of detail to things - cigarette butts around the trash bins, books with fine detail, and some very questionable artwork, which brings me to my next point.The entire game is a very long and drawn out story about how the white man is superior, and you should persecute non-whites, as well as the Jews. And why would you do this? Because you're super religious and that's what your prophet wants of you. A fair amount of blatant and subtle racism takes place, and the story expects you to just roll with it. The whole thing was more of a cheap addition of "lolz look racism mmmm fatalism" instead of making people look at moral or ethical decisions.Early on the game they even present that to you - you make the moral and ethical choice of choosing Elizabeth's broach - a  free bird or a cage. I chose cage, because ♥♥♥♥ that constipated ♥♥♥♥♥. As I played along with someone who chose the bird, I noticed that the game is identical. No matter which path you chose, it ends at the same conclusion and they wrap it up with "well that's just how it is, everything is decided for you" and circle jerk it a bit harder. Normally I would add a spoiler warning, but I'm not in this case, because I want to prevent other people from wasting their time and money on this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Elizabeth is your daughter, and you end up dead. Oh and it was also multiple realities, so she's not dead, and you're not dead. It then implies that BioShock 1 and 2 are also alternate realities. At this point I was so annoyed by the level of terrible going on that I let the credits roll in case it was a joke. When I realized it wasn't a joke, I uninstalled the game. Since then I have reinstalled it to play the Season Pass that was thankfully $5 during the Steam sale, thinking it would finally give me the great content I wanted. (I am told that the multiplayer for BioShock 2 is actually the game I was expecting, so we'll see)Nope. You start out exactly how I pictured the game - in Rapture, it's gritty, gorgeous, and how the damn thing should have been. Then Elizabeth leads you on a 45 minute circle jerk about fatalism and alternate realities. You meet the Little Sisters as they first form, which is cool, and then you're trying to rescue one. You fight a Big Daddy, which is a joke - just cheese the Tears and you win. Then you see the rest of your flashbacks, which are the other realities, and then Elizabeth kills you with the help of a Big Daddy because you're an evil man in another reality. In summary: the people who made this game took a massive religious♥♥♥♥♥♥ then wiped their collective asses with the BioShock name and called it a game. Don't buy it. Just don't. Take the money and stuff it in a stripper's thong. Or buy something else, like Super Meat Boy. Or Recettear. Or $30 worth of chicken nuggets. All of these things are far more valuable than this♥♥♥♥♥♥show.

Posted: December 8, 2013
												I bought this when it came out for 360 because I was a huge BioShock fan. Mistake.This game is NOT bad, it is a downright overhyped dissapointment. It looks great and works generally fine, there is no amazing soundtrack (not that big a deal), but where it falls short is the content.GAMEPLAY: Gameplay is horribly repetitive. The false sense of open space is actually more confining than the actual confined space found in the first two games. Gameplay consists of pathetic "vigors" that have no taste and all have trap versions. The guns are underpowered generally, don't seem cool, and the removal of the weapon wheel is a bust as ammo is no longer conserved. The sky-hook is insanely broken. What could have been the selling point of the game (and kinda was) was boring, repetitive, and screwed up your objective beacon. The Elizabeth tears were alright but anoyying and the constant backtracking was a strain.ENVIRONMENT: The environment is dirt. At first, the environment is cool; walking around a steampunk 1900s racist city and all, seeing the magical tech at work. As soon as the tears start happening and you start running around, you realize how boring it all is. The game doesn't feel like a fight for survival and freedom on a floating city - it feels like MMO quests in first-person on a bunch of blimps. The best level when a "scare"-factor is actually involved comes too few and too late.STORY: The story is linear and bland. The main story is fairly guessable and not fleshed out. Voxophones, which are like the audiorecorders of old Bioshock, offer little and are too hard to get too. The DLC storylines are too blatant in their fit to the paradoxy of Infinite, getting those weak fools who enjoy this game to drool over the worst dialogue ever.CONCLUSION: A total buchery of one of the best games I've ever played. Removes all the good elements of bioshock 1 & 2, has a ridiculous story, awful environment, and the vigors (the point of bioshock) are extremely underplayed and have no story implementation. What was once a survival horror game is now the posterchild of absurd MetaCritic scores.A good game, not what it should have been. Kind of like a Halo 4 but even more dissapointing. 75/100

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Very few games move me enough to have me consider a second play through. BioShock Infinite is one of those games. From the story to the combat, I have enjoyed every last second of the Columbia experience. Please don't compare this to previous games with similar titles... and as such I will not compare them in this recommendation. What I will do is explain what I love about Infinite, and if it jives with what you also love in games, then you will enjoy this experience as well.For one, without any spoilers, the story is tremendous. Not Dickens or Shakespeare, but for Sci-Fi fans who enjoy stories that try to stretch the imagination, this definitely satisfies. Columbia itself is nicely fleshed-out with a lot of details. It's nice to see a city that is seemingly pleasant until you see the underlying fanaticism and bigotry. It is almost uncomfortable and off-putting, but makes the experience that much more real.Besides story and setting, the remaining piece would be combat, of which I found quite satisfying. If you're not a fan of bullet-spongy baddies you've definitely come to the wrong place. I played through on Hard the first time, and the game definitely gave me a challenge. With only two weapons to swap between and a limited amount of Salt for Vigors (read Plasmids), I had to be very careful. It was easy to get myself killed by running out into the open; movement and cover is key. Most of the weapons are satisfying although at first I was a bit confused by the red and blue ammo (each faction has similar weapons with their own sets of ammo); I think subsequent play-throughs I will focus on upgrading a handful of specific ones instead of spreading myself so thin. As far as Vigors are concerned, I have to admit I enjoyed some more than others. While many where useful, when I eventually got "Return to Sender" and "Bucking Bronco", I was in love. There is a good variety of the usual suspects such as fire and electricity, and some interesting combos you can get (and there is an achievement for finding them all if you're into that sort of thing) by say lighting someone on fire and then charging them to create a bunch of fire-bombs that spread throughout the area. Character building in Infinite is mostly about what weapons you upgrade, what Vigors you buy and upgrade, but also is a little bit about clothing. There are four pieces of clothing Booker can wear, each with its own passive bonus. A lot of the best clothing is found through exploration, so make sure you poke around the levels if you want to find something good. Over time you will find a set of gear that will complement your play style which is especially satisfying.For me, this is a game that will stay on my hard drive for a long while. I'm not much for clutter, so usually uninstall games after completion. While not as consistently replayable as Borderlands, I certainly expect to go through this story again as well as the two Burial at Sea DLC packs. If what I've written piques your interest, then go ahead and buy this game. Still unsure? It's old enough that you can find it somewhere online at a discount, so you really don't have much to lose. It's time for you to go visit Columbia today!

Posted: January 1, 2014
												This is the first game that I've ever played that was bad enough to bother writing a negative review for. The uninspired combat system (and controls that leave no middle ground between "not turning" and "spinning in circles", even with an adjustable sensitivity mouse) doesn't hold up to those of the previous games, this game's plasmid equivalents ("vigors") provide uninteresting powers, and without them being a central plot point, or even having any obvious significance in the story, it seems that they exist solely so that Infinite could be called a Bioshock game.The story itself is so ridiculous that, if you read it in a book, you'd think it was a satire (and Poe's law be damned, no one could take it seriously). It follows the story of a floating city filled with a fanatical religion dedicated to the (literal) worship of America's founding fathers and also racism, possibly best exemplified by a bar where the the most prominent feature is a mural of a haloed John Wilkes Booth shooting Abraham Lincoln (complete with horns and red skin), visited not long after hearing a sermon about Washington crossing the Delaware (Incidentally, said mural was the point at which I closed the game and started looking up reveiws and "let's plays" to see if it got any better. Spoiler alert: It doesn't.). I surmise that the rationalization behind this schizophrenic mix of ideological parodies is this: the average person is not, in fact, violently opposed to either nationalism or religion, so to properly vilify your opponents (the general populace of Columbia) heavy handed (even anvilicious) racism was tacked on to remove moral ambiguity and guilt the other aforementioned ideologies by association, thereby justify shooting all the people who were literally just giving you free food and money.The writing was painful, too. The shift to a vocal protagonist was by no means a good one, since being reminded of what you should be thinking by your own character's voice makes for a shallow experience ("Augh! These heights are so scary!" during a mediocre above-ground experience where falling to your death is, in fact, impossible), not to mention that every third voice clip was to the tune of "huh?" or  "what's going on?".I won't even get into the time-traveling multiverse garbage.It's really a shame, because I really enjoyed the previous 2 games in the series, but Infinite seems like a poor attempt to capitalize on the reputation of a popular franchise in spite of, essentially, being the worst possible political commentary on nothing at all.In the interest of fairness, I have to admit that the game looks really nice, but fancy graphics do not a good game make.

content:
Posted: January 20
												Everyone I know, knows I hate this game with an absolutely searing passion.Heavy spoilers, obviously.Before it's release, I was pretty excited for this game, pre-ordered a physical copy, paid extra for release date delivery. Besides the factor of simple hype, the previews made the game appear promising, made it look like a genuine innovation.The game pretended to extend an offer of deep, layered gameplay, varied enemy types, upgradable powers, and multiple ways to navigate given situations. It made a pretense of suggesting that it would tell a fulfilling and engaging story, one that, like it's predecessors, was enveloped in stories about extremist ideologies and their effects.If you expected any of these things from this game, that would be a mistake.However, I'm here not only to argue that the game is pitifully mediocre when stood next to the other two games in the franchise; rather, I'm also going to argue that the game is just pitifully mediocre all things considered.Let's get the positives out of the way.The game is beautiful, the colorful saturation of Columbia is great. Additionally, there's some great, albeit wasted, potential for a good story in the themes the game plays around with about sin and rebirth.Now, to the bulk of it, why this game is horrifically overrated and not even anything above mediocre.On its concept, this is supposed to be a city of nativists, of Americans who want to limit admittance to 'some' and exclude the 'foreign hordes'. There's lots of insane worship of the founding fathers and a lot of racism. Totalitarian collectivism too. Solid foundation for a setting, you could tell a story with all these different issues right? Well, Infinite isn't doing that, it has no interest in doing that.None of these ideas or problems are explored with any nuance or even with any gravity, there's no bite to the racism and no force to the ideology -- it is nothing BUT a setting, the game isn't commenting on or even showing different perspectives about any of these ideas. Instead, we're served up half-baked 'dad rescues his daughter multiverse adventure'! Yay!I think, when you analyze the twists and turns of the story, there's plenty of absolutely absurd and ridiculous plotholes in all the universe hopping that Elizabeth and Booker participate in -- I've heard plenty of rationalization, it doesn't work, this isn't well thought out, it's not a masterpiece, stop.However, I don't think that it's bad because of those plotholes. I think, even leaving those aside or assuming they don't exist, it's just a pretty weak story that lacks for any sort of meaning. The problem isn't the plotholes, the problem is that the writers decided to forgo crafting an interesting world that is telling human stories to write this ridiculous multiverse tale that is essentially one giant wink at the player.BioShock and BioShock 2 tell stories with specific characters, they have antagonists, protagonists, conflicts and resolutions. BioShock Infinite on the other hand, just like Star Wars Episode VII, is essentially just a huge, obnoxious wink saying, 'Hey, remember BioShock?'This story is the BioShock of all the BioShocks! All those BioShocks were just crude reflections of this BioShock, this is the real one! -- is what the writers are trying to communicate to the player.It's as if Ken Levine, looking at the previous entries to the series, the stories they told, and faced with the daunting task of telling a new story, presenting a new world, just shrugged his shoulders and said, 'What if we just presented the *appearance* of a new world and a new story, but actually, it was just this 'meta' wink and nod to the previous games and wasn't a story of it's own at all?Even worse, it's as if Levine couldn't convince himself that he was really making something new or interesting, so he retroactively explains the plots of the previous two games as simply different iterations of Infinite's. It's like he knows, he knows that this story has obnoxious similarities to them, he knows he's creatively bankrupt, and he knows that he's not trying to tell a new story here.Don't despair, says Levine, it's actually a brilliant stroke of genius! There's always a lighthouse, a man, a city, etc.! No! I didn't run out of ideas! Shut up! It's really clever! No one will notice how stupid and utterly empty of meaningful content this is!It's true, the other two games also had lighthouses, men and cities. You know what else they had? Real characters who received real development and real characterization. A city that had an actual history and had real themes to present. The common elements never made the game, rather the writing, the characters, and the environmental storytelling did.Here, Ken Levine is left in the figurative shadow of the lighthouse, and, unable to be bothered to tell a new story, this game's story is some strange attempt to convince the player that the shadow of the lighthouse and the city, the simple, boring frame of the elements common to all 3 games ARE THEMSELVES a sort of meta-narrative about a father who sold his daughter, who sinned and atoned, and who ultimately rescues her.Can I just ask a question? What in God's name IS this garbage? Why does it exist? If Ken Levine wanted to tell a story about a father who sinned and lost his daughter but ultimately made it right, why didn't he just do that? The basic framework I just described does NOT require that it be linked through multiverse sci-fi magic BS to the other titles, it doesn't require any multiverse magic nonsense at all!It's not even a good story if you think of it not as a BioShock game. It's hardly even a story as much as it is just some weird-sounding BioShock fanfiction. GUISE WHAT IF, LIKE, ALL THE BIOSHOCKS BOIL DOWN TO A MAN TRYING TO SAVE HIS DAUGHTER FROM AN IDEOLOGICALLY EXTREME CITY? THEN THE NEW GAME WILL JUST BE THIS CONSTANT WINK THAT SAYS, 'OUR WRITERS GAVE UP!' WOULDN'T THAT BE EPIC AND A GOOD FOUNDATION FOR A STORY?NO! THE ANSWER IS NO!What if, in Halo 4, there was no narrative, it was actually this pseudo-intellectual garbage where, in the end, Cortana explains that in an alternate universe, Chief IS the didact and they're just playing out the latest iteration of Chief's attempt to save her, but in reality, there's always a Spartan, there's always a girl, there's always the covenant.Essentially, what if you take the elements common to all the games and then try to tell a meta-narrative that makes all the conflicts and characters insignificant as it explains them as simply another iteration of the same, unavoidable pattern? Does that make for a brief 'wow' moment when the player has this explained to them? Yes. Does it make for a good story? No, no it doesn't.It is, at it's core, the absence of a real story or of real writing. It happens when the writers mistake the common elements for actual writing or simply run out of ideas.Hey, though, that's just the story, right? What about the gameplay? It's bad too!Hi! What is a gun-upgrade system in a game with a two weapon limit where you switch weapons frequently b/c of limited ammo? The correct answer is pointless!What are a series of powers and abilities against enemies that all die in a few shots in constrained, linear shooting galleries? Useless? Yes!What is a rail system that allows for some amount of mobility but is mostly just used as a transition or for cutscene setpieces? A gimmick? Yes!What are transdimensional tears in reality? Are they varying ways to approach a given situation? No, they're not, they're just pointless!What is a 10-hour long campaign of shooting galleries that plays like a Call of Duty campaign but with a plot that is less-well executed, with all of the mechanics and depth that made its predecessors interesting removed? One of the most critically-acclaimed games of all time? For some reason, haha, yes! Kill me!Haha, wow this game sucks!

												One of the worst sequels ever made. Everything is a step down from the original: Story, gameplay, setting. Everything.Gameplay is Call of Duty tier: kill hordes of mundane enemies over and over completely lacking any thought or satisfaction in the deed.  Guns are terrible. Seriously, there is not one gun in the game I do not reflect back upon with utter distain. In the original Bioshock weapon and plasmid upgrades were bought through separate resource pools. But in this game, EVERYTHING, and I mean EVERYTHING, is bought through the same pool. This means you don't have any room to experiment with the "Vigor's" (which are just cut & pastes from the older game), and have to invest in solid shoot'em'up tactics because when you get right down to it, Vigor's are just something to call this game a "Shock" game and not a "Call of Dutes" game. You can only carry two guns at once, and there is easily 10+♥♥♥♥♥♥tier guns polluting the gun pool with their ammo. Which means in certain engagements, your main upgraded guns will likely run out of ammo and you'll be forced to use terrible re-skins in their place. Shooting guns is sticky, slow, tedious and all around not fun.Story takes a dive 1/4th into the game and from there on its a run and gun shoot'em up, all the way to the end with its exceptionally ill thought out ending (which doesn't resolve anything), but makes scrubs who don't want to feel stupid for not getting the ending shower it in praise for "depth", when in actuality it's simple, dull & poorly thought out. Ken Levine Scrapped the real Bioshock Infinite when he ran out of time wasting it on MP no one wanted, and was forced to put this♥♥♥♥♥♥out on the market. Literally, nothing promised in the original hype was delivered. Everything was recycled from the REAL Bioshock Infinite to create a presentable new game, and it certainly shows. Especially in character dialogue.Setting is un-imaginative and in comparison with Rapture, Columbia doesn't hold any water (no pun intended). In Rapture, the city felt like a living enemy. The ocean and crumbling city always loomed with you, and you were always aware that you were in a tin-can with a sheet of flexi-glass between you and death. In Columbia, you can just jump off the side and insta respawn with no consequences Super Meat Boy style. Enemies lack explanation or purpose in the world of Columbia, (take the fireman & patriot) & those that do are incredibly un-original or just half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥(crow racist people, Handy-Man).If you buy this game, I have no sympathy for you. Enjoy your middle of the game♥♥♥♥♥♥tier boss battle with Ghost lady 3 times over, while trying to justify your purchase by telling people like me "it was 2deep4u".

Posted: October 29, 2013
												There will be Spoilers.I was very disappointed with this game, having played it after finishing the first Bioshock game. The writing seemed very lazy, offering cliche time travel explanations for much of the experience, and unrealistic character behavior left and right. The character of Elizabeth was not particularly likable and was a complete Mary Sue (pretty much flawless, unrealistically skilled in various implausible facets). The storyline concerning her didn't very much interest me. I could not relate to her at all.The main Protagonist, Booker Dewitt, was a bumbling nobody who toppled an entire nation, capable of challenging the United States, single handedly. We have all seen many games able to pull off this type of protagonist in more believable ways than Infinite. He comes off as some cliche " evil with a heart of gold"  type of guy. I happen to be sick of this type of character.I didn't like the low amounts of ammo found in the game, and how you would have to abandon your upgraded weapon for a cheap handgun many times due to the lack of ammunition and the limited number of carried weapons allowed at one time. Superior weapons found near the end of the game also reminded you of the useless thousands of dollars spent into upgrading the earlier weapons.I am used to the tedium of backtracking in video games and I don't usually count it against a game unless it is exceptionally tedious. In a game where there are MULTIPLE UNIVERSES, why are the revisited areas almost exactly the same? Some color being different, or a swapped out statue in one universe was not enough to impress me, and it felt cheap and lazy (Does the same architect posess the ability to traverse worlds and walk planes of realitiy through tears in space/time, just like Elizabeth?Seriously?).Vigors. Useless, useless vigors. I was very disappointed with the vigors. Throughout the entirety of the game, as soon as the lightning Vigor was available, it became the exclusive one used. Barring the times where the game needed you to use a different Vigor ability to progress, Lightning was more than enough to get through the game easily, especially with the upgrades it unlocks. That is not to say I would have wanted to use any of the other vigors anyway, they seemed so boring and useless to use. Why don't enemies use Vigors? Except for those few special enemies with increased health, why don't average Columbians use Vigors? What's up with that?Elizabeth being able to lockpick seems like a forced reminder to keep the illusion of how useful she is. It's strange how many large, important places of interest have their security entrusted to the same cheap, flimsy lock. Columbia sure would be a breeze for Jill, the master of unlocking, to get around in.Only two weapons at a time. You can only carry two. Irrational games decided to hate fun this time around, I suppose. It's not like there is any large tactical advantage or disadvantage to carrying one over the other, it's like they tried to go for realism in this lone, weird gesture, when they tried it with nothing else. All it did was leave you no option, in some situations, but to weild a rocket launcher in a small narrow corridor, ensuring that you would lose precious health.Constants and Variables. That is what Elizabeth tells you after you inquire about the nature of the tears in space/time. "Constants and Variables?" "Yes." and it is left at that.Yeah, whatever you say, Irrational Games.You cannot carry medkits or salts. Why not? "Because we said so", say the men in the cubicles.This game sucked.

												This game is absolutely amazing. You can tell that there was an enormous amount of thought put into every detail, down to the very last corner. Bioshock Infinite is my favorite game to date, no question about it.To start, the art direction is very good. Everything is arranged to be very appealing, and the colors are very balanced. I loved just walking around the city and soaking it all up. There are 1912 style shops to go into, and they are all populated. In one area, there is even a good, three-minute quartet that you can just sit and listen to. I was very impressed with the magnitude of everything. Seldom are you placed in a small, dark room or hallway. Most of the game is set in colorful areas with large statues and airy buildings.I liked that it did not actually put you in the dark, but gave a dark feeling when it was appropriate. As per the Bioshock games, some of the events are quite dark, and I liked the uneasy feeling without the dark corridors of Rapture.Combat is a step up from other games in the genre. The introduction of "skylines" allows you to jump quickly from place to place, making everything very fast paced. I didn't quite like the inventory management as much as in the original Bioshock, however. I found it much harder to deal with my Vigors, mainly because you couldn't just scroll through them like in the other game. Still, you get used to it - that's a fairly minor gripe.I can not say much about the story. If I told you what was so great about it, I would spoil it for you. I can say that it puzzled me, and it was a few hours after finishing the game that I worked everything out. I felt like some of the points were repeated too much though. I get that they try to help everyone understand it well, but I would rather just have it all thrown at me - that way it's more fun to work out on my own.Overall, Irrational Games has gone above and beyond what anyone expected. The only way you would find this game worse than the original is if you are somewhat nostalgic. Even if you did not like the first or second game, I highly recommend that you still give Bioshock Infinite a try. As a side note, there are a few things that you will not quite understand if you skip the first game. They are little details, but in a game like Bioshock Infinite, it is the little details that really count.This game is worth every cent. If you can not afford it, you can wait until the next sale. The trilogy tends to go for $15~.Some screenshots:

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												(Mostly spoiler free)When all's said and done, a fairly disappointing game. The gameplay is certainly subpar, with lots of elements removed from previous titles. There is a nicely large variety of weapons, but this is completely undermined by the utterly unnecessary two weapons limit, which serves only to stifle player choice and undermine the upgrade system as well. Enemy variation isn't much to write home about. The regenerating shield is the first time that regenerating health has been tried in this series, and unfortunately really hurts the combat, since it makes cowering behind boxes and popping out to fire one of the most effective combat tactics. Also the only boss fights which occur in this game are terrible. Not just hard, but horribly designed: infinitely respawning enemies, limited weapons and a bullet sponge boss, with money deducted and enemy health restored every time you die.The story starts off quite strongly, although as more of the plot is revealed, plot holes spring up all over the place and the conclusion is confusing, rife with its own plot holes and unsatisfying. The world is also poorly constructed, with the player murdering hundreds of innocent people for the crime of being law enforcement officers, then continuing to have normal conversations with Elizabeth, making Booker seem completely insane. Vigors are an adapation of plasmids from earlier games, but while plasmids were integral to the plot in Bioshock, vigors are very much an afterthought, with basically no bearing on how the city operates.Elizabeth as a character is confusing. She has spent her whole life locked up in a tower, yet seems to be normally socially adjusted, which seems unusual. As a gameplay element, she is strangely shoehorned in. She cannot be injured or captured by enemies, who will completely ignore her, and can occasionally "find" ammo, health or salt (vigor power) around the battlefield, although these are not available through standard searching, only through Elizabeth. Her addition to gameplay is redundant, and only serves as an excuse for poor design in terms of ammo.Visual design is fantastic, but there is little else to recommend about this short game, especially replay value. Don't buy it.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Bioshock Infinite is a gorgeous first person shooter that takes place in a utopian, steampunk version of early 20th century America. The story centers around Booker Dewitt, a man who enters the floating city of "Columbia" looking to capture a certain girl as part of a deal to have his debts "wiped away." This game is very pretty to look at, and the gameplay is solid for a shooter game.Pros:+Solid shooter gameplay. The ability to purchase ammo from vending machines means you can often keep your preferred weapon for a long time, rather than simply using whatever you find like in most shooters. There is a wide variety of weaponry to choose from.+"Vigors," basically supernatural attacks with limited use, also add to the gameplay.+The game takes place in a utopian city in the sky. The amount of detailing put in to the environments is very high. It's a very pretty game to look at from start to finish.+Probably one of the most unique stories I've seen in a game. Having seceded from the Union, the city of Columbia flew into the sky. Now ruled by a corrupt religious cult, the city's beautiful exterior hides the intense racial discrimination and corrupt religious practices going on within.+The ending is unexpected and stuck with me for a while after finishing the game.+Multiple difficulties available, plus an extra hard "1999 mode" that gets unlocked after beating the game.+Above average Linux port.Cons:-Only lasted me 19 hours, and I play slow.-No multiplayer.-Ocassionally the game gives too many hints rather than just letting the player just figure things out for themself. However, this game is almost 100% combat and no puzzles, so this problem is almost negligible.-Sometimes the game makes you hit odd keyboard keys, like the enter key for example. This is a horrible key choice, since hitting enter means I have to reach all the way across the keyboard. However, this is never requested of the player during combat, so it isn't a real problem.This game's length can change drastically based on how much the player goes out of their way to explore the environment. Exploration yields money, ammo, health and other things. I tried to explore every area as much as possible, so my 19 hour game time is probably higher than average.Overall this game is a sight to behold. For those for whom FPS is their favorite genre, missing this game would be like stabbing yourself in the foot. Back when it was new and on a $60 price tag, the game's underwhelming length would have been a discouragement for some. But now that it is a couple years old and half the price, it's more than worth it.

												Bioshock Infinite review,What can I say? This game pushed the boundries of the original bioshock, literally. From a city under the sea, to a city in the sky. This game was simply amazing. A private detective named Booker Dewwit has been involed in a indebting with the wrong people, so, he is sent by them to find a girl named 'Elizabeth' who has been trapped in the city in the sky. (AKA. Colombia). Booker soon finds out that this is no ordanariy job, but in fact, something above his standards (Pun intended). As he explores the town of colombia, The backstory of the founder (Zachary Hale Comestuck), and every single barrel and garbage bin for coins and food. He soon finds out that there is a man who is called the 'False Shepard', an enemy to colombia. as you go deeper into the city you find out that the 'false shepard' has a sort of signiture for himself, two initials  on the back of his hand spelling A.D. Which to his suprize are the excact same initials Booker has on the back of his hand.The game always keeps you guessing from the start, and even to the end. With the genres switching from an action to a sort of horror. With reacurring enimies with increaced difficulty. And what bioshock is best at, The twists.This is one of the most enjoyable and mysterious games i have ever played with as little flaws as possible. I would reccomend it to anyone who asks me about it.I give it a 9.5/10

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Bioshock Infinite.No game has made me care more than this. No game has left me wanting more than this. No game can compair to this. This game is not JUST a game, It's a medium. A medium for all games now. This is a game that you can hold up to people who are against games as a medium, and show them that games CAN and SHOULD be taken seriously. This is a game that has been perfected to the very highest that is humanly possible. Not only are the game functions amazing, what adds to this game and makes it what it is, are the Characters, Story, Setting, and Voice Acting. No other game has had this high of a production value in a very long time, delayed three times, Worked on since 2006, 7 years in the making. This game shows that now, gaming as a medium can be just as good as this, maybe even better. The aesthetics and atmosphere add for immersion, the characters are beleivable, And you CARE about them, The gamplay, while simple, can bring players even further into the immersion. You can't mention Bioshock Infinite without bringing up Elizabeth, She's the, If you will, "Brains" of the game. The game would not be the same without her. Her movements are realistic, her expressions are full of life, and her personality is lovable. During combat she throws you supplies and can get you in to all kinds of locked gates, doors, and safes, Which in turn makes her even better; as she adds to the gameplay immersion while not being in the way. There are plenty of weapons, vigors, and you can't forget the fast-paced Skylines. The story is what makes this game what it is as well. From the start you know something is wrong with the city, some...dark undertone that you can't put your finger on. Since the Original bioshock was such a shocker with its chilling twists and turns in the plot, Everyone expects this game to have a twist, you'll be waiting for it, thinking you're ready, but when it comes...Oh trust me; You will NOT be ready. This game is revoutionary, it does new things, while keeping that old Bioshock feeling, The city of Columbia feels life-like, Elizabeth is possibly, The best A.I. ever, And the story keeps you entertained, and by the end; you'll be wanting so much more. Buy this game. It's worth it. If you don't like games, get it. If you are just a casual gamer, this is a game you can hold up and be proud that you spent your time on it. content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
 "Booker, are you afraid of God?""No, I'm afraid of you." Disclaimer: While I don't talk about things that are major to the plot, I WILL talk about things that were revealed before the game was released.TL;DR: Overall, it's amazing. The story is great, but sometimes illogical and clichéd. The combat has been downgraded from BioShock 2, but it is still good enough that you can have fun for probably like 2 playthoughs(enough to see everything the game has to offer). Everything else is great, especially the sound.BioShock Infinite is the third installment to the BioShock series, and if you really look at it, it's BioShock 2. The real BioShock 2 is an expansion more than anything to BioShock 1. So, BioShock Infinite is as tradition, a story-driven narrative FPS game. It's been critically acclaimed and is considered the 'best FPS ever made', and I met a LOT of people calling it 'perfect'. A lot more than you would definitely expect. Then is BioShock Infinite that good? Not really. But that happens with games. And this game is still really really good.The game takes place in the flying city of Columbia. You are Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton and now a hired gun, sent to Columbia to rescue a girl trapped within the city in order to pay off a debt. The most interesting of all choices Irrational made with BioShock Infinite is that they implemented a talking protagonist- not just a talking protagonist, but there are backstories and plot-related things that are surrounding him. Ken Levin himself, the head writer for BioShock 1 and this game, said that making a talking protagonist was a LOT harder to write with then a silent one. So seeing that change was a bit surprising, but not that major since this game takes in a completely different but similar environment than the previous games.Columbia, in hindsight, is a beautiful city, but you'll quickly find out that the entire city is built on Nationalism(specifically on America) and Racism, and the city is a social commentary on these issues, and I enjoyed them. Though, the city is also built on religion, which at first was weird because BioShock 2 was a bit about religion, but Ken Levine was NOT involved in BioShock 2 whatsoever, so that can be accepted.But the entire game is actually in fact NOT about these philosophies. For some reason, folks at Irrational wanted to make BioShock Infinite about alternate dimensions. Huh. Weird approach, but I really liked it. Not very original, but they still somehow managed to fit it in with the world and the execution was great.So let's elaborate on these alternate dimensions. Elizabeth, the girl you have to save, has the power to open 'Tears', which is a doorway to another world. It works both in gameplay AND the plot; you can summon guns or cover and such from the other worlds to aid you in battle, or sometimes you'll just go to another world! Though you can't just make Tears out of thin air(the game say Elizabeth COULD, but now she can't).I won't talk about the story longer- but trust me, it's really good. I don't think it's as good as what people say, and I think it's not THAT original and clever, but the character interaction(which I can't talk about for long) and the writing itself really won me over. But... let's face it, in BioShock games; in ANY FPS games, you're going to be running around and shooting people. Then shoot people again. Watch a cutscene(not in this game though, there aren't that many cutscenes), and shoot some more people. At least, for 50% the time, you're going to be shooting people, not listening to characters talk. That's why the gameplay is so important, and this is where BioShock Infinite fails only a bit.First problem. You can only carry around two weapons. ...yes. There are NO explanations for this, even though in the previous BioShock games you could carry around 10 ♥♥♥♥ing guns at once, in this game, you can't do that. This really limits the tactical choices you can do in the combat because you can't predict the future. There'll be a point where you would say "I wish I had this and this gun right now", and that's not good. It prevents the player from having fun.There is also a lot of stuff they took out such as the Research Camera. Now I'll admit it, the Research Cameras in BioShock 1 and 2 were a broken mess gameplay-wise, but they still somehow worked and it fit right in the sci-fi heavy world that BioShock games have. They could have easily fixed it and put it into the game, put they decided it wasn't worth their time.This game also has some RPG elements with upgrades and such, which was present with BioShock even before it came out with System Shock. But the upgrades in Infinite are really dull and disappointing. You have your generic 'Damage Boost 1/2', 'Recoil Decrease', 'Reload Increase', etc. Really really dull. And I'm emphasizing this because BioShock 2 had great upgrades that were tied in with the Cameras. With the Rivet Gun, if you upgrade it fully, you can set people on fire! How cool is that! Not very useful admitibly in late-game, but still cool and it shows they put effort into it. Not in Infinite though.They HAVE implemented a brand new feature: Gears. You can get different kind of hats, shirts, pants and boots and they will give you passive upgrades to you, similar to Gene Tonics from the previous games. Unlike weapons, you can switch out Gears at ANY TIME. Wow. They did this with Gears but not weapons. I still don't understand that... but anyways, the gears are actually pretty fun to use(unlike Gene Tonics) and it also heavily encourages exploration as they will be your prime rewards for exploring the world, and BioShock has always been about exploration.There are also not a lot of enemy types, and this one enemy called the 'Siren' is basically just a chore to fight in higher difficulties. While this is a thing with a LOT of FPSs, it still doesn't excuse it. What I DO like about the gameplay is just the rest of it: the guns overall feel satisfying, but the actual gun variety is also pretty small. And 'Vigors', which are basically Plasmids, has more of the same concept, but the execution is done MUCH better then Plasmids. But again, sadly, there are only a few Vigors in the game.One things I also really like are the Sky-Lines and the Freight Hooks. You can climb on to a Freight Hook and gain height advantage, or ride around in these semi-monorails and fling around and such, It's really fun to use and the Gears also encourage the players to use Sky-Lines since there are a lot of Sky-Line related Gears. There is also a 'Shield' mechanic in the game; not original and not very well executed. A lot of times it pops out of nowhere and ruins the immersion.Let's talk about some minor parts. The graphics are vastly improved, and the world is very colourful. But there are some parts that are reminiscent of the original horror-type environments of BioShock 1 and 2. The sound design is AMAZING. Occasionally, you will hear present-day Classic Rock songs converted into 1910s-type western-feel songs, and boy, they are amazing covers. They are definitely one of the best part in the entire frickin' game.I COULD'VE gone for another paragraph about the game's story(and how it sometimes doesn't make sense), but the writing is just great in general and the storytelling is also great that you should experience it yourself. I personally thought some parts didn't add up, and some parts are only explained in the DLC, and some parts are just clichéd, but overall it was great.Overall, BioShock Infinite is an amazing game. Definetely would have been GOTY if it wasn't for the best game ever made(GTA V, wink wink) that also came out in 2013. I urge you to grab ALL of the BioShock games, and grab the Season Pass for this game as it adds a story DLC that wraps the entire series up nicely. I give BioShock Infinite a 8.8/10, it's a must own for its fairly cheap price tag.

Posted: April 27, 2014
												When this was coming out, everyone was calling it Game of the Year, that is, until The Last of Us came out, an then GTA V came out. While I didn't play any of these two, I can definietely say that Bioshock Infinite deserves to be called Game of the Year.Many FPS games today are basically multiplayer with little to no single player campaign. This is not the case. This is a big, well-made singleplayer adventure set in the floating city of Columbia , in the year 1912. The story is told in a good way with all the cutscenes done in-game.Graphically, the game is stunning, the environment are beautiful and sometimes artistic and the lighting effects are amazing. The characters have a rather semi-realistic look, nut that doesn't mean the game is not serious. This is what this genre lacks in general: COLORS. It's really nice to see a living, more colorful areas instead of gray or brown. The animations were smooth and nice too.I really liked the music and all those radios etc. playing in the city. It really makes you feel like you're the part of the world. I really liked the voice acting as well. When it comes to gameplay... I loved it, and I'm not a great fan of first person shooters. You get to use a range of different weapons as well as several powers to use against your enemies. The combat is solid and works well. Aside from weapons and powers you can also use melee attacks with a Sky-Hook that also allows you to cling onto freight hooks and go along rails in the air which is awesome. There're other things to do aside from just going to your goal and killing those who oppose you. All throught the world you'll find audio files of different characters, which add some detail to the story, as well as small old-school videos and telescope to look into. Even upgrades for health, salts and shield are often well-hidden, so the game really wants you to explore more, instead of just going from point A to point B. The game took 11 hours to beat for me and I have found majority of collectibles, I still had some left. The game still was a little short in my standards. It was still REALLY worth it, especially for the price since I loved every second of it. I loved the presentation, I loved the gameplay, the powers, the characters. It is clearly a game where developers put EFFORT into it.I'll probably get the DLC and the previous games in the series because I just want more. Classic Rating:Grapics: 10/10Sound: 10/10Gameplay: 9/10Longetivity: 8/10Overall: 10/10

												Buy. This. Game. Now....no seriously. I'll wait. Oh, you haven’t bought it yet? And you want a (average) review on it? Alright then, here it goes. This is a masterpiece. People are relating it to Half Life 2, and Uncharted based on how good it is. It currently holds a meta critic score of 96/100 which is almost unseen of. The graphics and visuals in this game are absolutely stunning. You can easily get lost in this game's atmosphere looking for money, looting every corner of every place you visit, listening to the conversations between NPCs, reading the extremely well-designed advertisements located on walls, posters etc... I can go on all day. The amount of love and craftsmanship that went into this excellent piece of work is jaw-dropping. If you have the chance play this game on Ultra Settings, the graphics are almost better than life, its that good. Take the time to look at the detail on your weapon, or a poster on a wall, and I assure you, you WILL NOT see any sort of distortion or pixels (except when zooming in with a sniper). That my friends, is how detailed the world is. The gameplay pretty decent honestly, but nothing to special. You have your standard FPS gameplay, shooting your weapons, blowing off enemies’ heads and what not, but also has its own twist. Similar to the old bioshock titles, you can equip and weapon in one hand while casting lightening spells at your enemies with the other, or perhaps sending a flock of crows to eat away at your enemies flesh as you gun him down. The story as you progress is very good. You start to form a relationship with the character Elizabeth as she aids you throughout the game (also her character design is awesome, like something out of a Pixar movie). Toward the end of Bioshock Infinite the story starts to go full circle. But without spoiling, I did scratch my head for a good 5 minutes toward the last 30 seconds of the game, trying to figure out what just happened. But once I figured this interestingly beautiful (in an odd way) ending, I was satisfied. Sadly thought this game took me about 8 hours to complete on Medium, which is quite decent. I also play a lot of FPS games so there wasn’t much challenge for me. But next time I get the chance I will be doing a Hard run, just to give myself a bit more of a challenge, and to relive the atmosphere.Turn off all the lights in your room, put on some high quality headphones, turn the graphics on Ultra (if you can), and strap in because Bioshock Infinite, is easily going to take hours of your life away, as you explore this beautiful and extremely detailed world. Bioshock Infinite easily earns a 9 / 10.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												Most of us have all played the stellar Bioshock 1 and 2, and we've all made the obvious comparisons in our head when we think of Bioshock Infinite: the weapon limit, linear level structure, and a new mind-bending story. Among the top complaints are these three nuances that play an exceptional and pivotal role in Infinite; to some, the streets of Columbia are too linear when compared to the openness of Rapture, to others, the new weapon system doesn't adequately compliment the new baddies, and to a stubborn select few, the story simply either makes no sense or isn't quite as memorable as the first installment. To each his own, I suppose, but when we consider these "faults" to hold the experience back, we make room for further diminishing of the series as a whole. We have to feel some empathy for the developers at Irrational and understand what kind of thought was put not only into Rapture's cavernous tunnels, but Columbia's banner-ridden streets.Unfortunately, I won't go into any detail about that stuff, because I don't (or didn't) work at Irrational, I wasn't there for the writing process, and I've never seen how these concepts fly into Ken Levine's head. What I CAN do, lacking this information, is NOT compare Rapture and Colombia at all. Bioshock Infinite is in a completely new setting, with completely new characters, and while it may follow some similar ideas and share a basic plotline, what we know about either game is so NOT subjective, so NOT interchangeable that it makes no sense to start comparing at all. They share the same title, so what? Vigors or Plasmids? Who cares? What difference does it make if Bioshock wants to take us into the sky for an adventure we can't quite explore so well as an underwater palace? There's a lot less room for walking up in the sky, mind you.If you found fault in the game not because you found inconsistencies regarding this and the 2007 giant, but because you simply couldn't get a grip on the controls, the mechanics, or the story, by all means, you have your victory, and there's no sense in fighting over a cause you've already won. However, I have one message to those who insist to deem such tremendous games to be similar only because they share rather malleable concepts: BREAK THOSE CHAINS. ARE YOU A MAN, OR ARE YOU A SLAVE? I'm not trying to insult, I'm not trying to incite argument, I'm only trying to remove the slight tarnish that comes with a reputation, be it good or evil. When Bioshock decides to move a few miles up out of the water, you COMMIT, you don't QUESTION why it's moved or try to calculate the actual distance between the two.Again, to each his own, but I don't like sitting back and watching a game become progressively reviled because it is by law a member of the Bioshock series and therefore must be treated as inferior to its predecessor. In time, all things will eventually pass, and I should save my ranting for the future, but for now, I hereby declare that you will find no error in any three of these games. Should you find error in any of them, please make certain that you are judging the game in its own right. While there are some franchises that DESERVE the compare/contrast treatment (Assassin's Creed and Call of Duty are the ostensible ones), Bioshock is NOT one of them.Buy it, play it, love it. Just don't let the gritty bluish sepia of another masterpiece ruin this one.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												I've never really had a favourite game. Favourite book? Yes, Favourite film? Yes. But never a game, there were so many great ones that I couldn't separate. At least until I played Bioshock Infinite & it took my Number 1 slot by a mile! In fact, before I would put the game on such a pedestall, I played it again within 6 months. I actually enjoyed it even more than the first time.I was gifted Biosock 1 by a friend as I like immersive, story driven games. Not only was the plot engaging & inovative, & the gameplay interesting & open to different styles, the game was a set in a fabulously good looking location. However, it built itself up so well, that a boss fight wasn't enough to do the story justice & I was left wishing they'd actually finished the plot, instead of simply ending the game.Bioshock 2 was more of the same, adding lots to the universe but resolving little. A good game on it's own, but didin't really do anything new.I expected more of the same from Bioshock Infinite, but I'm happy to say, I was left utterly, stupidly & soundly corrected.Bioshock Infinite takes what made Bioshock 1 & 2 great while learning the lessons of the earlier game & in the process did something I have never seen in a game: make an NPC the lead character...The game is set in 1912, in a cloud city called Columbia, which is another beautiful setting to play out the story, with a clever rail system you can travel along & dive-bomb onto enemies or gun them down from the rail. Either way, you can become death from above & is a brilliant addition & makes Columbia feel like it is in the air. And yes, you can fall to your death. Or make an enemy fall to their death. Great fun.The guns are period weapons, & like all Bioshock games, they can be upgraded for bigger clips, reduced recoil, bigger hitting power etc, but unlike Bioshock 1, the guns dont change appearances. Previously, guns have gained mechaincal devices that are doing the job of the upgrade. It feels like a step backwards, but it's a small gripe & one of the few I can find. Ammo can become scarce for certain weapons as you go through the game, but as before, there are vending machines dishing out health & ammo, so if you have the money, you can keep your guns stocked.You also have Vigours; abilities that let you shoot electric bots or fireballs, or even flocks of deadly crows. You need Salt to 'power' these & is picked up or purchased like ammo. Known as Plasmids in Bioshock 1 & 2. They give great tactical flexibility, you can use them or not, the game leaves it up to you. The variety is nice & I found I used all the different Vigours more often than Plasmids, although I did stick to combos that worked with the type of weapons I choose.The plot is layered really nicely. If you just want to shoot stuff, then there is a fairly simple "get this girl & bring her back" plot to enjoy, with a fairly relentless & fanatical antagonist (Comstock) pursuing you. However, delve deeper & there are ideas & commentaries on equality, racism, revolutionaries, religion, fanaticism, science, morality & even time travel. There are son many levels tp engage on & this helps to hide the fact that Bioshock Infinite is a pretty stright, linear FPS, no sandboxing here my friend, but this helps pacing so well that, trust me, you won't notice it at all. On my second play through, even knowing the plot, I felt like I got more involved in the game as I know the characters & their stories.On the characters, there are the Letuce twins, who provide some comedic & satarical relief, hiding the fact they are actually important componetns of the story, Comtock; a fanatical, charismatic leader who after a few taunts at your character, you really want to beat. Your character, a guy called Booker De Witt & I should tell you, he is a complete a*rehole. In fact, 1st play through, I almost wanted him to end up the bad guy & get what he deserves! You character is pretty unlikable throughout, although he does develop into a better man towards the end, but he remains a perfect anti-hero because he never really becomes the hero. The other thing to say about Booker is that the story of Bishock Infintite is NOT primarily about him. Of course, he is a major character in the story, as is Comstock, but the story is about an NPC, the girl you are sent to Columbia to recover; Elizibeth.Elizabeth is one of my truly favourite things about Bioshock Infinite in that the decision to make her the main character & keep her with the player throughout was made early & stuck to relentlessly by Irrational Games. Even when it seemed impossible to make her work the way they wanted her too, Irrational stuck at it. And this tenacity makes Bioshock Infinite stand head & shoulders above all but a handfull of games, of any type.During combat, Elizabeth ducks out of the way, keeping out of the line of fire, but chucking you ammo, health & salt occasionally, but you can't rely on this all of the time as the supply varies throughout the game. Once the combat ends, she emerges safe & sound. Occasionally, when she's ahead of you, she is in enemy sight, but they ignore her but open fire instantly when you're spotted. Again, a slight flaw, but it happens on few occasions so is one I'm happy to forgive. This means, the rest of the time, she can make conversation with Booker, grow as a character & give the player a chance to invest in the story that unfolds around you both. She has a wonderful, stubborn niavity that is steady worn down through the game & she matures into a much 'older' version of herself, which is reflected as her clothes get damaged & torn, she cuts her hair & she picks up injuries at set pieces.For some reason, my first thought when I saw her was that she reminded me of Belle from Disney's Beuty & The Beast, both in her initial character, dress & hair syle, but it may just be me. Either way, Elizabeth is a fantastic innovation both as a character to grow, develop & revolve a plot around & as a technical acheviement of making her function properly through what is occasionally a frantic FPS.I mentioned Irrational learning lessons from the previous 2 Bioshock's & the biggest is how to end a plot, which is not finished by a boss fight & a cut-scene. There is a boss fight, a fairly tough one, but after that, there is about 20mins of 'game' left as you are taken through the plot, tying up all the strings that have been laid down into a fabulous bundle that left me really, really wanting more, but utterly satified all the same. There's no combat, very few choices the player needs to make, but I was so enthralled I barely noticed 1st time around. It was only when I reached the actual end, when the story was finally unravelled& revealled that I noticed I'd finished the FPS bit some time ago. It wasn't quite the ultimate hairs-standing-on-end, but a few stood up for me, even the second time around.Basically, if you like immersive, story driven games with good characters & a beautiful setting to play it all out in, then Bioshock Infinite is a game you absolutely MUST play, as it is one of the best. No argument. So go & buy it before it's too late, as there are rumours all 3 games are due to pulled from Steam.I cannot put into words how highly I recommend Bioshock Infinite.

Posted: August 13, 2014
												Okay. This is going to be an in-depth review of the game as a stand-alone game, and as a part of the series, divided by the various elements that make a game, well, you know, a game.Gameplay:As a Part of The Bioshock Series (assuming you have already played them):Seriously lacking. They replaced the Power To The People Station with simple and cheap ways of weapon upgrades, which is, as a part of the series, a dissapointment. They replaced the plasmids with vigors which are frankly awesome, but not THAT new. What was new was the introduction to traps, which was very well handled. But what I cannot forgive is that they took away the ADAM gathering, and moved away its upgrades to simple vending machines, giving the game a much easier experience, apart from the serie's particular difficulty. 8/10As a Stand-Alone Game:Different, innovating, thrilling and rewarding, not to mention hard. Vigors kept the experience fresh, and the guns were well balanced. Good work. 9/10StorylineAs a part of the Bioshock Series: Good enough. It provided new and fresh ideas, but keeping the feel of being a Bioshock game. The unfolding of the story trough voxophones is brilliant, and, as compared to the stories in previous games, much, much more coherent and entertaining. 9/10As a Stand-Alone game:An absolute Masterpiece. Mind-blowing, exciting and amazing in every way. The characters are beautiful, the voice-acting is tremendously well done, and, not to spoiler anything, an ending worth crying for. 10/10Other elements:Animation: Perfect in every way. Very well done. Way better than the series (due to the fact that most of the main character in previous installments had little to no screen time) 9/10Soundtrack: Very well put toghether as actual parts of the storyline. 9/10DLC's: Absolute must haves. (Maybe Clash In the Clouds not as much) but the Burial at Sea series are definetly worth getting. ESPECIALLY if you played both previous Bioshock games. They may have their own reviews later on.Graphics/art: The art, as it's common among the Bioshock games is absolutely, amazingly beautiful. Therefore, the graphics are really, really good. 10/10Overall:As a part of the Bioshock Series: 8.5/10.    The gameplay changes were a serious letdown.As a Stand Alone Game: 9.7/10

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
 "Booker, are you afraid of God?""No, I'm afraid of you." Disclaimer: While I don't talk about things that are major to the plot, I WILL talk about things that were revealed before the game was released.TL;DR: Overall, it's amazing. The story is great, but sometimes illogical and clichéd. The combat has been downgraded from BioShock 2, but it is still good enough that you can have fun for probably like 2 playthoughs(enough to see everything the game has to offer). Everything else is great, especially the sound.BioShock Infinite is the third installment to the BioShock series, and if you really look at it, it's BioShock 2. The real BioShock 2 is an expansion more than anything to BioShock 1. So, BioShock Infinite is as tradition, a story-driven narrative FPS game. It's been critically acclaimed and is considered the 'best FPS ever made', and I met a LOT of people calling it 'perfect'. A lot more than you would definitely expect. Then is BioShock Infinite that good? Not really. But that happens with games. And this game is still really really good.The game takes place in the flying city of Columbia. You are Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton and now a hired gun, sent to Columbia to rescue a girl trapped within the city in order to pay off a debt. The most interesting of all choices Irrational made with BioShock Infinite is that they implemented a talking protagonist- not just a talking protagonist, but there are backstories and plot-related things that are surrounding him. Ken Levin himself, the head writer for BioShock 1 and this game, said that making a talking protagonist was a LOT harder to write with then a silent one. So seeing that change was a bit surprising, but not that major since this game takes in a completely different but similar environment than the previous games.Columbia, in hindsight, is a beautiful city, but you'll quickly find out that the entire city is built on Nationalism(specifically on America) and Racism, and the city is a social commentary on these issues, and I enjoyed them. Though, the city is also built on religion, which at first was weird because BioShock 2 was a bit about religion, but Ken Levine was NOT involved in BioShock 2 whatsoever, so that can be accepted.But the entire game is actually in fact NOT about these philosophies. For some reason, folks at Irrational wanted to make BioShock Infinite about alternate dimensions. Huh. Weird approach, but I really liked it. Not very original, but they still somehow managed to fit it in with the world and the execution was great.So let's elaborate on these alternate dimensions. Elizabeth, the girl you have to save, has the power to open 'Tears', which is a doorway to another world. It works both in gameplay AND the plot; you can summon guns or cover and such from the other worlds to aid you in battle, or sometimes you'll just go to another world! Though you can't just make Tears out of thin air(the game say Elizabeth COULD, but now she can't).I won't talk about the story longer- but trust me, it's really good. I don't think it's as good as what people say, and I think it's not THAT original and clever, but the character interaction(which I can't talk about for long) and the writing itself really won me over. But... let's face it, in BioShock games; in ANY FPS games, you're going to be running around and shooting people. Then shoot people again. Watch a cutscene(not in this game though, there aren't that many cutscenes), and shoot some more people. At least, for 50% the time, you're going to be shooting people, not listening to characters talk. That's why the gameplay is so important, and this is where BioShock Infinite fails only a bit.First problem. You can only carry around two weapons. ...yes. There are NO explanations for this, even though in the previous BioShock games you could carry around 10 ♥♥♥♥ing guns at once, in this game, you can't do that. This really limits the tactical choices you can do in the combat because you can't predict the future. There'll be a point where you would say "I wish I had this and this gun right now", and that's not good. It prevents the player from having fun.There is also a lot of stuff they took out such as the Research Camera. Now I'll admit it, the Research Cameras in BioShock 1 and 2 were a broken mess gameplay-wise, but they still somehow worked and it fit right in the sci-fi heavy world that BioShock games have. They could have easily fixed it and put it into the game, put they decided it wasn't worth their time.This game also has some RPG elements with upgrades and such, which was present with BioShock even before it came out with System Shock. But the upgrades in Infinite are really dull and disappointing. You have your generic 'Damage Boost 1/2', 'Recoil Decrease', 'Reload Increase', etc. Really really dull. And I'm emphasizing this because BioShock 2 had great upgrades that were tied in with the Cameras. With the Rivet Gun, if you upgrade it fully, you can set people on fire! How cool is that! Not very useful admitibly in late-game, but still cool and it shows they put effort into it. Not in Infinite though.They HAVE implemented a brand new feature: Gears. You can get different kind of hats, shirts, pants and boots and they will give you passive upgrades to you, similar to Gene Tonics from the previous games. Unlike weapons, you can switch out Gears at ANY TIME. Wow. They did this with Gears but not weapons. I still don't understand that... but anyways, the gears are actually pretty fun to use(unlike Gene Tonics) and it also heavily encourages exploration as they will be your prime rewards for exploring the world, and BioShock has always been about exploration.There are also not a lot of enemy types, and this one enemy called the 'Siren' is basically just a chore to fight in higher difficulties. While this is a thing with a LOT of FPSs, it still doesn't excuse it. What I DO like about the gameplay is just the rest of it: the guns overall feel satisfying, but the actual gun variety is also pretty small. And 'Vigors', which are basically Plasmids, has more of the same concept, but the execution is done MUCH better then Plasmids. But again, sadly, there are only a few Vigors in the game.One things I also really like are the Sky-Lines and the Freight Hooks. You can climb on to a Freight Hook and gain height advantage, or ride around in these semi-monorails and fling around and such, It's really fun to use and the Gears also encourage the players to use Sky-Lines since there are a lot of Sky-Line related Gears. There is also a 'Shield' mechanic in the game; not original and not very well executed. A lot of times it pops out of nowhere and ruins the immersion.Let's talk about some minor parts. The graphics are vastly improved, and the world is very colourful. But there are some parts that are reminiscent of the original horror-type environments of BioShock 1 and 2. The sound design is AMAZING. Occasionally, you will hear present-day Classic Rock songs converted into 1910s-type western-feel songs, and boy, they are amazing covers. They are definitely one of the best part in the entire frickin' game.I COULD'VE gone for another paragraph about the game's story(and how it sometimes doesn't make sense), but the writing is just great in general and the storytelling is also great that you should experience it yourself. I personally thought some parts didn't add up, and some parts are only explained in the DLC, and some parts are just clichéd, but overall it was great.Overall, BioShock Infinite is an amazing game. Definetely would have been GOTY if it wasn't for the best game ever made(GTA V, wink wink) that also came out in 2013. I urge you to grab ALL of the BioShock games, and grab the Season Pass for this game as it adds a story DLC that wraps the entire series up nicely. I give BioShock Infinite a 8.8/10, it's a must own for its fairly cheap price tag.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												When this was coming out, everyone was calling it Game of the Year, that is, until The Last of Us came out, an then GTA V came out. While I didn't play any of these two, I can definietely say that Bioshock Infinite deserves to be called Game of the Year.Many FPS games today are basically multiplayer with little to no single player campaign. This is not the case. This is a big, well-made singleplayer adventure set in the floating city of Columbia , in the year 1912. The story is told in a good way with all the cutscenes done in-game.Graphically, the game is stunning, the environment are beautiful and sometimes artistic and the lighting effects are amazing. The characters have a rather semi-realistic look, nut that doesn't mean the game is not serious. This is what this genre lacks in general: COLORS. It's really nice to see a living, more colorful areas instead of gray or brown. The animations were smooth and nice too.I really liked the music and all those radios etc. playing in the city. It really makes you feel like you're the part of the world. I really liked the voice acting as well. When it comes to gameplay... I loved it, and I'm not a great fan of first person shooters. You get to use a range of different weapons as well as several powers to use against your enemies. The combat is solid and works well. Aside from weapons and powers you can also use melee attacks with a Sky-Hook that also allows you to cling onto freight hooks and go along rails in the air which is awesome. There're other things to do aside from just going to your goal and killing those who oppose you. All throught the world you'll find audio files of different characters, which add some detail to the story, as well as small old-school videos and telescope to look into. Even upgrades for health, salts and shield are often well-hidden, so the game really wants you to explore more, instead of just going from point A to point B. The game took 11 hours to beat for me and I have found majority of collectibles, I still had some left. The game still was a little short in my standards. It was still REALLY worth it, especially for the price since I loved every second of it. I loved the presentation, I loved the gameplay, the powers, the characters. It is clearly a game where developers put EFFORT into it.I'll probably get the DLC and the previous games in the series because I just want more. Classic Rating:Grapics: 10/10Sound: 10/10Gameplay: 9/10Longetivity: 8/10Overall: 10/10

												One of the best stories ever told in videogame history, and one of the most elevate peaks in artistic direction ever reached by the industry. Anyway Infinite compensates with plot and characters, and still remains a must play.About the DLCs...they made a mess. Completely. I won't even talk about the "Clash in the Clouds" one because the only thing that crap is good for is proving that the combat mechanics of Infinite are very, very poor. About Burial at Sea...aside from the fact that splitting the new story arc in two was a really, really bad idea, after playing them you will be amazed and about to scream "MASTERPIECE" out of the window at first, but then you'll realize that everything you just saw literally made no sense with the premises left by the main game. Which is a terrible pity. They wanted to go full circle with the first Bioshock installment and make a deep and dramatic conclusion, but they just rushed things too much and made a lot of mistakes. Too bad, really.At least they gave us the noir version of Elizabeth. Which really compensates a lot. Believe me.

												Buy. This. Game. Now....no seriously. I'll wait. Oh, you haven’t bought it yet? And you want a (average) review on it? Alright then, here it goes. This is a masterpiece. People are relating it to Half Life 2, and Uncharted based on how good it is. It currently holds a meta critic score of 96/100 which is almost unseen of. The graphics and visuals in this game are absolutely stunning. You can easily get lost in this game's atmosphere looking for money, looting every corner of every place you visit, listening to the conversations between NPCs, reading the extremely well-designed advertisements located on walls, posters etc... I can go on all day. The amount of love and craftsmanship that went into this excellent piece of work is jaw-dropping. If you have the chance play this game on Ultra Settings, the graphics are almost better than life, its that good. Take the time to look at the detail on your weapon, or a poster on a wall, and I assure you, you WILL NOT see any sort of distortion or pixels (except when zooming in with a sniper). That my friends, is how detailed the world is. The gameplay pretty decent honestly, but nothing to special. You have your standard FPS gameplay, shooting your weapons, blowing off enemies’ heads and what not, but also has its own twist. Similar to the old bioshock titles, you can equip and weapon in one hand while casting lightening spells at your enemies with the other, or perhaps sending a flock of crows to eat away at your enemies flesh as you gun him down. The story as you progress is very good. You start to form a relationship with the character Elizabeth as she aids you throughout the game (also her character design is awesome, like something out of a Pixar movie). Toward the end of Bioshock Infinite the story starts to go full circle. But without spoiling, I did scratch my head for a good 5 minutes toward the last 30 seconds of the game, trying to figure out what just happened. But once I figured this interestingly beautiful (in an odd way) ending, I was satisfied. Sadly thought this game took me about 8 hours to complete on Medium, which is quite decent. I also play a lot of FPS games so there wasn’t much challenge for me. But next time I get the chance I will be doing a Hard run, just to give myself a bit more of a challenge, and to relive the atmosphere.Turn off all the lights in your room, put on some high quality headphones, turn the graphics on Ultra (if you can), and strap in because Bioshock Infinite, is easily going to take hours of your life away, as you explore this beautiful and extremely detailed world. Bioshock Infinite easily earns a 9 / 10.
