content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												In total, I give this game a 9/10, here is why:PROS:- Amazing Storyline- Easy to understand controls- Amazing Scenery (even on the lowest setting)- Variety of weapons, and way to go about the levels- Freedom to move around a bit (None linear levels in a way)- Many characters that are easy to understand and keep track of- Good variety of missions- Really tests your moral: Do what is right if it hurts people? Do what is wrong if it means no one will get hurt?- Elizabeth's ally skillsCONS:- Not a large variety of enemy types- Random ammo locations and ammo drops makes it hard to keep the weapons you want- Over viscious enemies that will not give inBoth, depending on your preference:- Jumpscare (Only one, but you won't be expecting it :P )A bit of spoilers beliw, but the main spoiler is at the bottom, so you can rwad below, and not spoil the ending,     The game is about a Mr. Booker De Witt, the character the player plays as, arriving to a light house, where a letter claims that Booker De Witt must bring "The Girl," in order to repay his debt. While exploring the lighthouse, he stumbles upon a chair that shoots him up into the sky, where he finds a floating city known as Columbia. There the people of the city seceeded from the U.S. due to Abraham Lincoln's Civil War, and became its own "state." There, the people worship George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and Benjamin Franklin, and follow the prophet and leader of their city: Mr. Comstock. Booker, bewidered by the place he stumbled upon walks around, allowng the player to learn how to play the game and ue each vigor as a carnival is going on show casing the different abilities the player will be experiencing. Everywhere he looks he sees posters of Comstock, and posters saying how he is the greatest man ever, and other posters claiming to avoid the "False Prophet," created to "stray the lamb away." One poster in particular claims that the "False Prophet," has the letter "AD" engraved on his hand, at this point Booker raises his hand to show the player that "AD" is on his own hand. As you are walking through the street, a note is handed to you, telling the player to NOT get #77 when playing the raffel that the city is doing that day. Lo and Behold, when you go and play the raffel and win, you got #77. You are given a baseball bat, and a black woman and Irish man is dragged out onto the stage and the announcer tells the player to throw it at them as the couple begs them. Here the player learns that the town is racist. The player is given their first choice in the game, throw it at the couple or throw it at the announcer. [I chose to throw it at the announcer] The player raises his hand, where a police officer grabs his arm, and points out the "AD," is on his hand. Instantly, people run, and you kill the police officer, stealing his gun, and the real game begins. You use the gun to shoot at the officer. The game progresses like this until you reach a tower, where you learn that the tower holds a girl hostage, Elizabeth. You free her, learn she can open tears (doors into other dimensions,) and that she is possibly the daughter of Comstock. The rest of the game is trying to find out who Elizabeth really is, and how to defeat Comstock and fix your life.      To begin, the storyline is amazing, and is constantly keeping me wanting more. While I played it on hard (for the first time,) I was constantly having a challenge and to me, that was fun. The characters developed nicely, evolving as the plot developed, which also fitted nicely into the journey your character was embarking on. However, while I say that, the main character seemed to not develope in character as in how the character percieved certain things or how the player reacted to certain events, it was always the same, a gritty "I don't want to be here," attitude; while this may be part of his character, it did seem to get a bit repetative.     Guns sounded nice, and did what guns are supposed to do. kill enemies in a realistic way. Upgrades could be purchased for the weapons and I admit that I did purchase a lot of them, but it is entirely up to player to buy upgrades, not only for the guns but for vigors as well. Vigors are powerups that the characters can use giving him special abilities, my favorite being possession; I rarely used the others however, but again, it is up to the player. Enemy variety is low, all characters that look one way also have the same type of gun, but do not carry the same gear when you search their dead bodies. These enemies range from anything to enemies with simple weapons and barely any armor (the police in the beginning,) to extremely hard (the helpers.) I will admit though, I did enjoy fighting all enemies when they showed up.)     Elizabeth, the character probably most people are familiar with, is an amazing ally. Constantly finding ammo, salts (item to use vigor,) health and pointing out items in the room you can grab. Without her, the player would have a hard time fighting. Her facial expressions are nicely done, changing as the story progresses. She mad at you? She will show anger, and talk to you differently. She will throw things to you without speaking, and show the player her anger by facing away from the main character: Booker De Witt.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The ending to the game was not something I could expect, especially when you find out Elizabeth is your daughter. It really makes you think about how you treated her in the game, and all the stuff that happened to her. Bottom line, you sold her.

												Had this game on Ps3 when it came out, and found it very indulging in story to the point where I may have spent a bit too much time playing it over and over for a week straight. The gameplay is just your average FPS variant due to the combination of guns and special powers called vigors that work in a similar way to plasmids from the first 2 games. The story is a fairly average one until you get more towards the end of the game where it finally all hits you and mind****s the hell out of you, and I did thoroughly enjoy it. Whilst the twist may not have had the same impact as the first Bioshock's twist did, it still was pretty much unseen for the most part and is worthy of appreciation as much as the first game was.If you have played the first 2 games, I think you will really enjoy this one. In my personal opinion I would put it ahead of Bioshock 2, but behind the original Bioshock, yet still a game worthy of the hype it received. If you like to play games based on the gameplay, and you're looking for a very good FPS, this MIGHT fit the bill but I would recommend it far more for the immersive story, the connections that can be made to the old Bioshocks, and the refreshing colour tones it brings for most of the game. (Oh - And of course all the crazy fan theories people come up with).Very enjoyable and well worth the download. Personal verdict - 9.5/10.

Posted: August 13, 2014
												Okay. This is going to be an in-depth review of the game as a stand-alone game, and as a part of the series, divided by the various elements that make a game, well, you know, a game.Gameplay:As a Part of The Bioshock Series (assuming you have already played them):Seriously lacking. They replaced the Power To The People Station with simple and cheap ways of weapon upgrades, which is, as a part of the series, a dissapointment. They replaced the plasmids with vigors which are frankly awesome, but not THAT new. What was new was the introduction to traps, which was very well handled. But what I cannot forgive is that they took away the ADAM gathering, and moved away its upgrades to simple vending machines, giving the game a much easier experience, apart from the serie's particular difficulty. 8/10As a Stand-Alone Game:Different, innovating, thrilling and rewarding, not to mention hard. Vigors kept the experience fresh, and the guns were well balanced. Good work. 9/10StorylineAs a part of the Bioshock Series: Good enough. It provided new and fresh ideas, but keeping the feel of being a Bioshock game. The unfolding of the story trough voxophones is brilliant, and, as compared to the stories in previous games, much, much more coherent and entertaining. 9/10As a Stand-Alone game:An absolute Masterpiece. Mind-blowing, exciting and amazing in every way. The characters are beautiful, the voice-acting is tremendously well done, and, not to spoiler anything, an ending worth crying for. 10/10Other elements:Animation: Perfect in every way. Very well done. Way better than the series (due to the fact that most of the main character in previous installments had little to no screen time) 9/10Soundtrack: Very well put toghether as actual parts of the storyline. 9/10DLC's: Absolute must haves. (Maybe Clash In the Clouds not as much) but the Burial at Sea series are definetly worth getting. ESPECIALLY if you played both previous Bioshock games. They may have their own reviews later on.Graphics/art: The art, as it's common among the Bioshock games is absolutely, amazingly beautiful. Therefore, the graphics are really, really good. 10/10Overall:As a part of the Bioshock Series: 8.5/10.    The gameplay changes were a serious letdown.As a Stand Alone Game: 9.7/10
